SUMMARY:
Nobel Laureate Malala Yousafzai has been trolled online for wearing a pair of jeans and heeled boots to university.
An unverified image of her was posted to Facebook by the Pakistani news outlet Siasat, where Yousafzai is seen wearing a bomber jacket and head scarf, as well as the jeans and heels.
pic.twitter.com/pZq6ucxI6B October 17, 2017Malala wearing jeans and a shirt in Oxford has started another debate.
#LetGirlsLearn #MalalaYousafzai #oxforduniversity pic.twitter.com/me0jfJhiFc â€” Shehneela Ahmed (@iamshehneela) October 17, 2017Trolling #Malala is the lowest of lows.
In 2014, when she was just 16, Yousafzai became the youngest person to be named a Nobel Prize recipient.
TEXT:
Nobel Laureate Malala Yousafzai has been trolled online for wearing a pair of jeans and heeled boots to university.

An unverified image of her was posted to Facebook by the Pakistani news outlet Siasat, where Yousafzai is seen wearing a bomber jacket and head scarf, as well as the jeans and heels. The post has attracted more than 2,000 comments.

The photo has attracted the attention of trolls on both Facebook and Twitter, who deem her choice of dress unacceptable.

My tweet in @DailyMailUK Now tell me what's more defaming Pakistan. Her jeans or the entire world reading how we all mocked her attire? pic.twitter.com/pZq6ucxI6B October 17, 2017

Malala wearing jeans and a shirt in Oxford has started another debate. Pious pakistanis were expecting burqah from her. â€” Ibrar (@IbrarIbrahim) October 14, 2017

Many others however, have hit back at the criticism, posting their support for the 20-year-old, thanking her for her courage in campaigning for girls' education.

Malala can wear whatever she wants she is an inspiration to everyone. Her courage inspires us all to keep fighting for girls everywhere to get the education they deserve. #LetGirlsLearn #MalalaYousafzai #oxforduniversity pic.twitter.com/me0jfJhiFc â€” Shehneela Ahmed (@iamshehneela) October 17, 2017

Trolling #Malala is the lowest of lows. She is free to be the woman she wants to be! https://t.co/DlFyYvOLJn â€” MD (@elephantcaravan) October 17, 2017

Purchased your book today for my granddaughter. You are an inspiration to females of every age around the world. Thank you. â€” Eunice Kokrda (@ekokrda) October 17, 2017

Yousafzai began her studies in philosophy, politics and economics at Oxford University in early October. Malala and her family moved to the UK after she was shot by the Taliban in 2012 for advocating for girls' education. In 2014, when she was just 16, Yousafzai became the youngest person to be named a Nobel Prize recipient.
TITLE: Malala Yousafzai Trolled Online For Wearing Skinny Jeans And Heels To Uni

TEXT:
Ahora que estoy sentada escribiendo mi primer post sobre las cosas que nadie me contÃ³ sobre trabajar desde casa, tengo que confesar algo. En primer lugar, que llevo la misma ropa que me puse anoche para dormir. Me he vuelto a poner la pijama despuÃ©s de baÃ±arme.

En segundo lugar, que tengo tantos proyectos inacabados en mente que pido disculpas de antemano si empiezo a desvariar. Por Ãºltimo, que mi compaÃ±era de trabajo, Allison Janney, estÃ¡ allÃ¡ al fondo en silencio, asÃ­ que tengo unos cuantos minutos para centrarme en escribir esto.

Hace ya diez aÃ±os que trabajo desde casa y, cuando se lo digo a la gente, suelen darme una de las siguientes dos respuestas:

1) Â¿En serio? Â¡Debe de ser maravilloso!

2) Â¿CÃ³mo demonios se consigue un trabajo asÃ­?

Aunque trabajar desde casa ya es algo normal para mÃ­, sigue siendo un desafÃ­o cada dÃ­a. Hay un montÃ³n de cosas de las que ojalÃ¡ hubiera sido PLENAMENTE consciente antes de aceptar mi primer trabajo desde casa. Â¿Con cuÃ¡ntas de estas te sientes identificado?

1. Rutina... Eso no existe

PrÃ¡cticamente todos los libros de autoayuda te dicen que la rutina es la soluciÃ³n para que una persona consiga organizarse y hacer de una maldita vez lo que tiene pendiente. Pero, Â¿dÃ³nde estÃ¡ la rutina cuando te pasas la semana entera en el mismo sitio, durmiendo tan cerca de donde trabajas y reuniÃ©ndote en cafeterÃ­as porque hacerlo en casa es poco profesional? AsÃ­ que no, no puede haber rutina.

2. No tienes que "prepararte" para ir a trabajar

Cuando un dÃ­a no hay ninguna reuniÃ³n, lo mÃ¡s probable es que no me "prepare" para ir al trabajo. Lo normal es que me ponga una sudadera o simplemente el pijama, con el pelo recogido en un chongo y sin maquillaje. No vale la pena molestarme. AdemÃ¡s, me cuesta segundos salir de la cama y encender la laptop. Y por eso mi ropa profesional de la universidad sigue colgada sin usar en el armario y llevo jeans cuando me visto.

3. Las tareas domÃ©sticas son el demonio

Cuando muchos de mis amigos con trabajos tradicionales tienen la ocasiÃ³n de trabajar desde casa por un dÃ­a, suelen decir que han hecho un montÃ³n de tareas domÃ©sticas que tenÃ­an pendientes. Me explican con orgullo lo mucho que les ha aprovechado ese dÃ­a en casa.

Sin embargo, cuando trabajar desde casa es la rutina habitual de todos los dÃ­as, esas mismas tareas domÃ©sticas se convierten en un demonio que te distrae del trabajo. Oigo que la ropa sucia, desde la rebosante bolsa en la que se acumula, me llama a gritos; la vajilla, limpia o sucia, tambiÃ©n reclama mi atenciÃ³n. No hay ningÃºn lugar en el que pueda esconderme de sus incesantes reclamos.

Y, aunque hable con mi marido de aumentar nuestra familia de dos miembros, no tengo ni idea, literalmente, de cÃ³mo puede trabajar una persona con hijos desde casa. Las interrupciones, distracciones y la falta de privacidad dinamitarÃ­an mi capacidad de trabajo.

4. Los compaÃ±eros de trabajo no son iguales

El silencio es ensordecedor y trabajar desde casa te aÃ­sla del mundo. Echo de menos la energÃ­a de los lugares de trabajo tradicionales. Actividad, ruido y conversaciones alrededor. Algunas personas se ponen mÃºsica. A mÃ­ me gusta hablar durante mi jornada laboral, asÃ­ que hago maratones de Netflix. Se ha convertido en mi compaÃ±ero de trabajo. Y sÃ­, le hablo a la tele a veces. AsÃ­ evito volverme loca.

Al trabajar desde casa no tengo ningÃºn sistema de asistencia. Soy mi propia asistencia, asesoramiento profesional y administraciÃ³n (y la mayor parte del tiempo no tengo ni idea de lo que hago).

5. No tengo ayuda

Al trabajar desde casa para una empresa o para un particular, no tengo ningÃºn sistema de asistencia. Soy mi propia asistencia, asesoramiento profesional y administraciÃ³n (y la mayor parte del tiempo no tengo ni idea de lo que hago).

TambiÃ©n implica que no tengo a nadie para intercambiar ideas o debatir, asÃ­ que, en cierto modo, siento que me quedo rezagada en lo que a crecimiento profesional se refiere en comparaciÃ³n con mis antiguos compaÃ±eros de clase.

6. Es difÃ­cil sentir motivaciÃ³n personal

Algunos dÃ­as me siento muy motivada y otros nada. Cuando trabajas en una oficina, al menos tienes que levantarte y arreglarte para ir allÃ­. SerÃ­a muy extraÃ±o que pudieras pasarte el dÃ­a entero mirando la pantalla de la computadora sin hacer nada. En casa, en cambio, los dÃ­as en los que te falta la motivaciÃ³n son los mÃ¡s difÃ­ciles de afrontar. Son los dÃ­as en los que las distracciones causan estragos, los dÃ­as en los que la disciplina es el Ãºnico as en la manga.

7. No existe el equilibrio entre la vida laboral y la personal

Mi laptop y mi iPhone van siempre conmigo. No puedo ir a ninguna parte sin llevar encima, como mÃ­nimo, uno de los dos. Da igual si es una noche, un fin de semana, un dÃ­a laboral... La frontera se difumina, sobre todo cuando mi marido llega tarde a casa y no tengo a nadie que me diga que es hora de apartar la vista de la pantalla.

Me he acabado dando cuenta de que, para lograr algo de ese equilibrio, tengo que salir de casa y rodearme de gente, olvidarme de las tareas domÃ©sticas y conversar con seres humanos.

Por todas las razones que he expuesto, por todas las que se me ha olvidado mencionar y para lograr algo de paz en mi mente, llevo un tiempo buscando alguna comunidad laboral a la que unirme para crecer personal y profesionalmente, hacer contactos, adaptarme a una rutina y concentrarme para poder, de una maldita vez, acabar lo que tengo pendiente. Como no encontraba una comunidad sÃ³lida, unÃ­ fuerzas con mi mejor amiga para crearla nosotras mismas: Haven Collective.

Este post fue publicado originalmente en HuffPost Estados Unidos y ha sido traducido del inglÃ©s por Daniel Templeman Sauco para El HuffPost.

*Este contenido representa la opiniÃ³n del autor y no necesariamente la de HuffPost MÃ©xico.
TITLE: Siete cosas que nadie me contÃ³ sobre trabajar desde casa

Die Kurden in der ethnisch gemischten Stadt fieberten auf das Referendum hin, das ihrer Region die nationale UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit bringen soll.

Doch nun, keine zwei Monate spÃ¤ter, kÃ¶nnte sich dieser Traum zumindest fÃ¼r die Kurden in Kirkuk ausgetrÃ¤umt haben.

In einer gezielten MilitÃ¤roperation haben irakische Einheiten und Soldaten der schiitischen Miliz al-Haschd asch-SchaÊ¿bÄ« am Montag das GebÃ¤ude der Provinzregierung sowie den MilitÃ¤rflughafen unter Kontrolle gebracht.

Auch die wichtigen Ã–lfelder auÃŸerhalb der Stadt Kirkuk fielen ohne oder mit geringer Gegenwehr der kurdischen Peschmerga-KÃ¤mpfer an die irakische Armee. Die kurdischen KÃ¤mpfer, die sich in Erwartung eines Angriffs zu zehntausenden in der Stadt versammelt hatten, haben sich offenbar ins Zentrum der Stadt zurÃ¼ckgezogen.

Auch PKK-KÃ¤mpfer sollen sich weiter in der nordirakischen Stadt aufhalten.

Die Stimmung ist hochexplosiv, es scheint, als kÃ¶nne der Krieg zwischen den Kurden und den Soldaten der irakischen Zentralregierung jederzeit losbrechen.

Viel steht auf dem Spiel. Denn es geht lÃ¤ngst um mehr, als um die Frage, ob Kirkuk, dessen IdentitÃ¤t â€“ kurdisch, arabisch, turkmenisch â€“ so umstritten ist, zu Kurdistan gehÃ¶ren soll oder zum Irak.

Viele Experten zeigten sich Ã¼berrascht Ã¼ber den rapiden VorstoÃŸ der Iraker. Denn die Peschmerga hatten schon in den vergangenen Tagen signalisiert, jeden Akt der Gewalt von Seiten der Zentralregierung mit Gewalt zu beantworten.

Kurdische KÃ¤mpfer in Kirkuk, bislang gab es wenig Gegenwehr, Quelle: Kurdistan24 TV, Reuters.

Auch die TÃ¼rkei steht hinter der Offensive

Doch es ist nicht nur der Iran, der den VorstoÃŸ gegen die Kurden unterstÃ¼tzt.

Ende September hatten die Kurden in einer Volksabstimmung fÃ¼r die nationale UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit gestimmt, auch Kirkuk sollte Teil eines neuen Kurdenstaats werden. International fand das Ergebnis kaum Zustimmung, auch die Regierung in Bagdad erkannte das Referendum nicht an.



Kurden-PrÃ¤sident Barzani bei der Stimmabgabe im September, Quelle: Reuters.

Nun fliehen die Kurden zu Zehntausenden aus Kirkuk. Karwan Wahed, der in Erbil und Umgebung als TouristenfÃ¼hrer arbeitet, sagte der HuffPost, die meisten Menschen wÃ¼rden versuchen, nach Sulaimaniyya oder Erbil zu gelangen. "Ich bin heute nur damit beschÃ¤ftigt, diesen Menschen zu helfen", sagte Wahed.

Bilder aus dem Nordirak zeigen verstopfte StraÃŸen, Kinder sitzen neben den Leitplanken, weil es nicht vor und nicht zurÃ¼ck geht. Alle wollen nur noch weg.

Ein Kampf um das Ã–l

Bei dem Konflikt geht es nicht nur um ethnische Grenzziehungen in der schwierigen Region. Es geht auch um Ã–l.

Kirkuk gilt als Ã–l-Hauptstadt des Landes, etwa die HÃ¤lfte der irakischen Ã–lexporte werden hier gefÃ¶rdert. FÃ¼r die Kurden, die ohne das Ã–l wirtschaftlich von Bagdad abhÃ¤ngig sind, ist der Verlust der Ã–lfelder fatal.

Jabbar al-Luaibi, Ã–l-Minister des Iraks, warnte die Kurden zwar, den Export nicht zu behindern, doch die angespannte Lage macht einen direkten Transport in die TÃ¼rkei hochbrisant.

Ã–zkizilcik erklÃ¤rte: "Dies soll durch die Einnahme von Sinjar und der syrisch-irakischen Grenzregion ermÃ¶glicht werden. Der GrenzÃ¼bergang ist westlich des Habur-GrenzÃ¼bergangs geplant."

Der Kampf um das Ã–l - Toprak sieht darin ein niederes Motiv, Kurdistan zu zerschlagen. "Die sunnitische TÃ¼rkei und der schiitische Iran arbeiten zusammen gegen Kurdistan. Sie wollen Kurdistan unter sich teilen", mahnte der Chef der Kurdischen Gemeinde.

Der Westen findet keine Antwort

Er appelliert an Deutschland und die USA, sich hinter die Autonomieregierung zu stellen. Denn die Kurden seien "der wahre VerbÃ¼ndete des Westens".

FÃ¼r beide LÃ¤nder ist die Lage aber hÃ¶chst zwiespÃ¤ltig. Denn sowohl die USA als auch Deutschland unterstÃ¼tzen beide Konfliktparteien, den Irak und die Peschmerga, mit Waffen und Ausbildern.

Bei Twitter macht nun das Bild eines irakischen Soldaten die Runde, der auf eine kurdische, eine amerikanische und eine deutsche Flagge tritt.

In die Auseinandersetzung reinziehen lassen will sich niemand. US-PrÃ¤sident Donald Trump erklÃ¤rte in Washington, die Vereinigten Staaten wÃ¼rden nicht Partei ergreifen. Die USA seien sehr besorgt Ã¼ber die Lage im Irak, sagte AuÃŸenministeriumssprecherin Heather Nauert in einer wenig entschlossen klingenden Stellungnahme.

Die Bundeswehr unterbrach derweil ihre Ausbildungsmission im Norden des Landes. Im Verteidigungsministerium ist die Rede von einer "unklaren Lage".

Dahinter steckt wohl vor allem die Angst vor einem neuen BÃ¼rgerkrieg. Eine Angst, die auch in anderen LÃ¤ndern wÃ¤chst.

Ein britischer Soldat, der in Erbil stationiert ist, sagte der HuffPost, die Situation sei besorgniserregend. "Eigentlich soll ich am Montag wieder nach Schottland fliegen, aber es sieht nicht so aus, als wÃ¼rde das klappen." Der internationale Flugverkehr wurde eingestellt.

Kurdistan ist isoliert und in die Enge getrieben. Dass eine Reaktion der kurdischen KÃ¤mpfer ausbleibt, daran glaubt im Irak wohl niemand.

Those Digital Files Look Great On The Wall: The Lost Art Of Printing So when did you last take a photograph? And when did you last print one? I'm willing to bet you probably took at least one photo today on your phone. But I'll bet you haven't printed any photos in a very long time unless you've just had school portraits done or got married! Everyone - young and old - has their own busy schedules, and this means that there may only be a few moments available every day for activities which involve both parents and children. Psychologist

What Happens When You Switch Off From The World For 48 Hours? The FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out) subsided and my head began to clear. I felt great, relaxed and refreshed to the point when I wasn't even thinking about my phone, freeing up my brain! A two night stay in the great outdoors felt like twice as long and I returned home vowing to take some applied learning's with me: Mum first. Savvy marketer, growing entrepreneur and lifestyle photographer second. Love helping others grow. Always trying to be brave.

I Went On Strike At Home On a normal day I dropped the kids at school, came home, and did all the jobs waiting for me. By the time I sat down to do any work the day was half gone, I was fed up and frustrated and had lost my motivation for doing any work on my business. "Zuma did well initially, he was willing to accommodate alliance members into ANC structures and accommodate their views on various issues.
Vavi said it is unlikely alliance members will make any considerable moves ahead of the ANC's national conference in December.
"I think they [the alliance partners] thought they could control Zuma when they voted for him in 2007.
TEXT:
Cosatu members cheer and dance as they march through the streets protesting against corruption on September 27, 2017 in Johannesburg.

Tensions have reached an all-time high between the ANC and its alliance partners. The SA Communist Party (SACP) has labelled President Jacob Zuma's axing of their boss, Blade Nzimande, as a declaration of war and trade union federation Cosatu has urged the governing party to reflect on its decision.

This while both alliance members have amplified their calls for the president to step down, but neither was provoked enough to step away from the mother body -- which is the ANC.

However, former Cosatu boss Zwelinzima Vavi says the move to detach from the ANC may come after the party's national conference in December -- if Zuma's preferred candidate, Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, is voted as the party's new president.

In his second Cabinet reshuffle for 2017, Zuma axed Nzimande (who is the leader of the SACP) from the helm of the ministry of higher education and training -- a move which the communists saw as a direct attack on the alliance.

Ministers who have served a mere 6 months moved to new positions. No strategy in this #CabinetReshuffle. Key is gas deal at energy. â€” Justice Malala (@justicemalala) October 17, 2017

At an urgent press conference in Johannesburg on Tuesday, SACP first deputy general secretary Solly Mapaila said the party's various structures would meet to discuss the way forward and make a decision on whether its members serving on several ANC constituencies would remain there.

Cosatu trod lightly on the matter, neither condemning the reshuffle or supporting it.

In a statement, the trade union federation said it found the frequency of Cabinet reshuffles "unsettling".

"These recent Cabinet reshuffles have done very little to help take the National Democratic Revolution forward. We call on the ANC to reflect deeply about the state of the economy and the overall performance of its government," it said.

"As Cosatu, we will continue to work with and support the newly elected ministers and deputy ministers with the hope that they will prioritise a people-driven and people-centred development. We wish them well in their new positions."

The SACP says theres been moralÃ°ical decay under Pres JG Zuma.Hai Fuseg Man!You were told this from 2005. You swore at those who said soğŸ˜‚ â€” Ebrahim Fakir (@EbrahimFakir) October 17, 2017

In an interview with the HuffPost SA, Vavi said the alliance should be used as a springboard for building unity among South Africans, but it only works to benefit the ANC during the election period. He described the phenomenon as a "dog-and-hunter syndrome".

"When the hunter goes on a hunt, he uses the dog to catch and fetch his target. But after the animal is captured, and the hunter eats it with his family at the table, he throws the bones out the window for the dog who is outside," Vavi said.

"The alliance has become like a broken record to the ANC now."

He said the alliance was already at a state of collapse during Thabo Mbeki's presidency and "in their anger" it moved "from the frying pan and into the fire" in petitioning for Zuma as president.

"Zuma did well initially, he was willing to accommodate alliance members into ANC structures and accommodate their views on various issues. Regrettably, by the 2014 elections, the relationship had broken down," Vavi said.

"I have been warning South Africa about this since 2010... Zuma moved from our [the alliance's] circles and into the circles of the 'premier league' around 2011 or 2012. He lost interest in the alliance then."

Vavi said it is unlikely alliance members will make any considerable moves ahead of the ANC's national conference in December.

"They won't walk away now but they are more likely to do so if [Dlamini-Zuma] wins. I think they are waiting for a Ramaphosa victory," he said.

Blade knifed to settle scores against SACP and appointment of David Mahlobovich to energy definite move to secure Zuma Russian nuclear deal â€” John Steenhuisen MP (@jsteenhuisen) October 17, 2017

Labour expert Terry Bell said it would be interesting to see what the SACP and Cosatu do now.

"Zuma is obviously trying to split the party... There has always been tension in the alliance," Bell said.

"I think they [the alliance partners] thought they could control Zuma when they voted for him in 2007. They thought they could manipulate him. But he is masterful and he used them instead."
TITLE: Vavi: Alliance May Fall Apart If NDZ Becomes President

Mais les policiers, jugÃ©s devant un jury exclusivement blancs, seront dÃ©clarÃ©s non coupables.

De n'avoir pas assez insistÃ© sur la dimension sociale des Ã©vÃ¨nements de l'Algiers Motel. D'avoir omis certains dÃ©tails. Ou d'avoir au contraire trop insistÃ© sur la violence des policiers blancs, faisant de cette violence un spectacle qui la dÃ©politisait.

En France, oÃ¹ il ne s'agit pas directement de notre histoire, encore que nous ayons nous aussi notre passif de violences policiÃ¨res Ã  l'encontre de jeunes hommes noirs et arabes, les rÃ©actions sont plus mesurÃ©es. J'ai tout de mÃªme eu la surprise de voir passer sur les rÃ©seaux sociaux des critiques dont l'argument principal se rÃ©sumait Ã  : Kathryn Bigelow est blanche, elle ne peut pas parler correctement de nous.

Je suis noire. Je suis rÃ©alisatrice et scÃ©nariste. A aucun moment, quels que soient ses dÃ©fauts, je ne me suis sentie offensÃ©e par "Detroit". Dire en revanche que "l'histoire des Noirs" devrait ou ne pourrait Ãªtre racontÃ©e que par les Noirs me semble dangereux Ã  deux titres. C'est, tout d'abord, revenir Ã  un essentialisme primaire. Ainsi, les Blancs ne pourraient parler que des Blancs, les Asiatiques des Asiatiques, les Noirs des Noirs, et ainsi de suite ? Mais en quoi Ãªtre Noir deviendrait-il, en soi, un attribut de lÃ©gitimitÃ©, voire de pertinence? En France, oÃ¹ il n'existe quasiment aucun film sur l'esclavage et la colonisation subssaharienne tant ces sujets demeurent tabous, on a eu droit il y a quelques annÃ©es au film le plus indigent qui soit sur l'esclavage: "Case DÃ©part", commis par deux acteurs noirs devenus rÃ©alisateurs: Fabrice EbouÃ© et Thomas Ngijol, dont j'adore par ailleurs certaines de leurs autres comÃ©dies.

L'autre Ã©cueil, c'est de considÃ©rer que l'histoire des discriminations raciales est l'histoire des autres, qu'elle ne concerne pas intimement chacun de nous, quelles que soient notre couleur de peau ou nos origines. La sÃ©grÃ©gation raciale aux Etats-Unis est autant l'histoire des Blancs que celles des Noirs. Comme celle de l'esclavage ou de la colonisation en France. Je trouve donc plutÃ´t sain que Kathryn Bigelow qui est blanche se soit sentie interpellÃ©e par la persistance des violences de son pays Ã  l'encontre de la minoritÃ© noire. Certes, on peut regretter qu'elle ne donne pas aux Ã©vÃ¨nements leur pleine dimension politique. Mais "Detroit" a d'autres mÃ©rites. Il nous Ã©pargne les sanglots de la culpabilitÃ© blanche, ainsi que le complexe du "sauveur blanc" qui inondent tant de films sur les Noirs faits par des Blancs. Il explore la dimension machiste du racisme des policiers Ã  l'origine des meurtres â€“ il y avait deux femmes blanches cette nuit lÃ  avec ces hommes noirs. Il n'hÃ©site pas Ã  nous montrer l'ambivalence du statut de ces femmes. MÃ©prisÃ©es par les policiers pour leur promiscuitÃ© avec des Noirs, guÃ¨re Ã  l'abri de violences sexistes parce que femmes, mais in fine mieux traitÃ©es parce que blanches. Elles-mÃªmes ne semblent pas conscientes qu'elles jouissent, du fait du privilÃ¨ge de leur peau, d'une libertÃ© de parole dont ne dispose pas leurs compagnons noirs. Est-ce cela, au fond, qui est reprochÃ© Ã  Kathryn Bigelow? Ses privilÃ¨ges de femme blanche Ã©duquÃ©e de la classe moyenne, ainsi que l'a pointÃ© le magazine Variety?

Le vrai problÃ¨me, ce n'est pas la couleur de Kathryn Bigelow, c'est pourquoi, aujourd'hui encore, il est si difficile pour les rÃ©alisateurs et les rÃ©alisatrices noir(e)s d'avoir la possibilitÃ© de raconter leurs histoires. Et comme on aime bien en France pointer du doigt les dysfonctionnements de la sociÃ©tÃ© amÃ©ricaine pour mieux mettre les nÃ´tres sous le tapis, permettez-moi de relocaliser la discussion ici, dans l'hexagone.

En France, on n'a pas de films comme "Detroit" (ou "Selma" ou "Twelve Years a slave") mais "Qu'est-ce qu'on a fait au bon Dieu?", Ã  croire que le racisme soit un sujet trop sÃ©rieux pour Ãªtre traitÃ© autrement que par la pantalonnade. On a eu aussi, dans un tout autre genre, "Bande de filles". Dans ce film sorti en 2014, CÃ©line Sciamma suit l'Ã©mancipation d'une jeune fille noire de banlieue Ã  travers sa bande de copines â€“ toutes noires. La critique a Ã©tÃ© dithyrambique, soulignant que le film donnait enfin Ã  voir des filles d'ordinaire invisibilisÃ©es. A l'inverse, gros Ã©nervement du cÃ´tÃ© des spectateurs et des spectatrices noires qui ont trouvÃ© qu'il s'agissait d'un ramassis de clichÃ©s, Ã  la fois sur les Noirs et sur la banlieue, de la part d'une rÃ©alisatrice qui se contentait de transposer ses fantasmes de petite bourgeoise blanche sur une rÃ©alitÃ© qu'elle connaissait pas.

Personnellement, je n'ai jamais vu dans "Bandes de filles" que l'expression subjective du dÃ©sir et de la fascination d'une rÃ©alisatrice blanche pour des jeunes filles noires. Mais les mÃ©dias ont voulu faire de ce film, LE film sur "les filles de banlieue", celui qui allait nous montrer qui elles sont, lui confÃ©rant de facto une forme d'autoritÃ© qu'il n'avait pas lieu d'avoir. C'est cela qui a Ã©tÃ© insupportable pour les spectatrices et les spectateurs dont on prÃ©tendait raconter le vÃ©cu quand eux-mÃªmes ont tant de mal Ã  se faire entendre dans l'espace social.

En France, au nom de l'universalisme, on trouve normal de parler des autres, de filmer les autres, sans se rendre compte que ce sont presque toujours exclusivement les Blancs qui parlent et qui filment. Ils le font d'ailleurs la plupart du temps sans mÃªme questionner d'oÃ¹ ils s'expriment, ni comment leur parole sera reÃ§ue par ceux dont ils parlent.

En 2015, j'ai rÃ©alisÃ© pour la tÃ©lÃ© un documentaire sur le racisme qui s'appelait "Trop Noire pour Ãªtre FranÃ§aise". Entre autres choses, j'y interrogeais plusieurs chercheurs comme Achille Mbembe, Pap Ndiaye... et le sociologue Eric Fassin. Celui-ci a expliquÃ© plus tard dans une interview qu'il avait pris la peine, avant d'accepter ma proposition, de vÃ©rifier que seraient filmÃ©s aussi des chercheurs noirs. Il ne voulait pas endosser la position du sachant blanc qui parle de l'expÃ©rience noire.

Combien de rÃ©alisateurs et de rÃ©alisatrices franÃ§ais font-ils preuve de cette humilitÃ© prÃ©alable? Une humilitÃ© que je peux, quoi qu'on en dise, percevoir dans le film de Khatryn Bigelow. Comme j'ai toujours senti dans les films de Claire Denis, qui m'ont aidÃ©e quand j'avais 20 ans Ã  me construire en tant que personne noire, la conscience de l'endroit Ã  partir duquel on parle de l'autre. Etrangement, ces deux donnÃ©es ont presque toujours fait dÃ©faut chez les producteurs et les financeurs du cinÃ©ma franÃ§ais avec qui j'ai Ã©tÃ© amenÃ©e Ã  discuter de mes projets de films pour le grand Ã©cran. Eux savaient ce qu'il fallait dire sur les Noirs. Et comment. Voire de quel type de Noirs il fallait parler. Cela ne correspondait pas Ã  ce que moi j'avais envie de dire? Qu'importe, ils avaient le pouvoir et pas moi. Ils savaient, tandis que je n'Ã©tais, aprÃ¨s tout, qu'une jeune rÃ©alisatrice inconnue. Et puis â€“ ce n'est pas le sujet de cette tribune, mais d'Angot Ã  Rousseau en passant par Harvey Weinstein ou le hashtag Balancetonporc, c'est d'actualitÃ© â€“, certains m'ont aussi fait comprendre que cela aiderait que j'accepte de coucher avec eux. Je n'ai pas couchÃ©. Je n'ai pas fait non plus de films pour le cinÃ©ma.

La plupart de mes amis rÃ©alisateurs noirs n'ont pas eu la possibilitÃ© de faire les films qu'ils souhaitaient. Ce n'est pourtant pas faute de talent. Certains, quand ils avaient des origines africaines, sont partis poursuivre en Afrique la carriÃ¨re qu'on leur refusait ici. Beaucoup ont fini par arrÃªter de faire des films. Les nouveaux qui arrivent luttent pied Ã  pied pour financer leurs projets, s'autoproduisent ou font appel au crowdfunding. Vous me direz qu'il est Ã©galement difficile pour un rÃ©alisateur blanc de trouver l'argent nÃ©cessaire Ã  la production de ses films. Certes. Mais de nouveaux visages Ã©mergent rÃ©guliÃ¨rement. Il a fallu, en revanche, attendre 33 ans pour qu'Ã  la suite d'Euzhan Palcy en 1984, deux jeunes rÃ©alisatrices noires soient rÃ©cemment distinguÃ©es aux CÃ©sar. VoilÃ  oÃ¹ nous en sommes en 2017.

Alors, que toutes les Kathryn Bigelow de France fassent tous les films qu'elles veulent sur les Noir(e)s, les Arabes, les Asiatiques. Y compris, aussi, lorsque ces rÃ©alisateurs choisissent de ne pas parler d'eux mais des Blancs, car il ne saurait y avoir d'altÃ©ritÃ© vraie que dans les deux sens.

Hay distintos asesinatos que se han cometido que, lamentablemente, no han sido resueltos, en ese sentido tambiÃ©n habÃ­a muchÃ­simos pendientes de los resultados de la instituciÃ³n".

PrÃ¡cticamente, la gran mayorÃ­a de los delitos que se cometen en nuestro paÃ­s, quedan impunes, por problemas serios del diseÃ±o de la FiscalÃ­a General, de la ausencia de una verdadera carrera ministerial, de la falta de capacitaciÃ³n de los elementos para hacer investigaciones puntuales y ahÃ­ estÃ¡n las consecuencias."

CERVANTES, REBASADO

Aunque hay grandes deudas en la procuraciÃ³n de justicia, el investigador reconoce el esfuerzo de Cervantes para iniciar con las aprehensiones de algunos exgobernadores, aunque, apunta, no queda claro, cuÃ¡l ha sido la cooperaciÃ³n que tuvo la PGR con las procuradurÃ­as locales para lograr las detenciones.

En el caso de Veracruz, claramente el tamaÃ±o del escÃ¡ndalo nacional ante los evidentes problemas de corrupciÃ³n que cometiÃ³ el exgobernador Duarte, creo que sÃ­ crearon la presiÃ³n suficiente para, no habÃ­a de otra, entrarle al asunto en ese caso.

Aunque recalca que sÃ­ hay cuestionamientos al desempeÃ±o del hoy exprocurador, el problema lo trasciende, pues revela la necesidad de una discusiÃ³n verdadera sobre cÃ³mo diseÃ±ar de forma distinta la FiscalÃ­a General.

"El problema es que nunca nos hemos dado como paÃ­s una verdadera instituciÃ³n que establezca las bases de investigaciÃ³n, que tengan los ministerios pÃºblicos, la capacidad de allegar bien los elementos para llevarlos ante un juez y poder procesar a aquellos que cometen delitos.

Todos esos defectos han estado siendo cada vez mÃ¡s visibles en los lastimosos casos de impunidad que retrata el paÃ­s y a los que el hoy exprocurador no contribuyÃ³ a su soluciÃ³n de manera sustantiva."

IRRESPONSABLE DEJAR SELECCIÃ“N HASTA 2018

El presidente Enrique PeÃ±a afirmÃ³ el pasado 16 de octubre que no hay condiciones para designar al nuevo Fiscal General de la RepÃºblica, por lo que estimÃ³ que ese nombramiento deberÃ¡ concretarse despuÃ©s de las elecciones de 2018, sin embargo "pensar que esto sÃ³lo se trata del nombramiento es una visiÃ³n muy obtusa, es no entender todos los problemas del diseÃ±o actual de la FiscalÃ­a y que para corregirse requieren de una verdadera reforma constitucional", revira FernÃ¡ndez.

Me parece una irresponsabilidad (del Presidente), porque lo que necesita el paÃ­s, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ del nombramiento de la persona, es en verdad entrarle a la discusiÃ³n del diseÃ±o de una FiscalÃ­a que pueda arrojar buenos resultados y eso pasa por una discusiÃ³n integral de la reforma, de entrada al artÃ­culo 102 y 116 constitucional."

El artÃ­culo 102 establece los procedimientos de cÃ³mo se va a nombrar al Fiscal y, para que pueda funcionar el resto de la reforma a lo largo del paÃ­s, se necesita establecer la disposiciÃ³n constitucional para que las procuradurÃ­as de los estados sigan el mismo modelo, de ahÃ­ la necesidad de modificar el artÃ­culo 106, explica el profesor.

EN RIESGO LO QUE RESTA DEL SEXENIO

Para el investigador de MÃ©xico EvalÃºa lo dicho por el presidente PeÃ±a Nieto es una tentaciÃ³n para la clase polÃ­tica, tanto la del gobierno como la de oposiciÃ³n, para no entrarle al tema en lo que resta de este sexenio.

Con franqueza quisiera pensar que esto va a ser distinto, pero yo veo muy difÃ­cil que se le vaya a entrar a ese tema durante lo que resta de este sexenio."

SeÃ±ala que aunque la oposiciÃ³n manifiesta estar dispuesta a discutir el diseÃ±o de la FiscalÃ­a General, hasta ahora no hay acciones concretas ni en la cÃ¡mara de senadores ni de diputados, mÃ¡s allÃ¡ del bloqueo del pase automÃ¡tico a Cervantes.

En el caso del PRI, en una reuniÃ³n un dÃ­a antes del temblor del 19 de septiembre, decÃ­an no ver condiciones para entrarle a una discusiÃ³n de reforma constitucional en la materia.

TEXT:
WASHINGTON â€• Katrina Johnson, the mother of a gender-fluid teenager who was shot to death last year in Burlington, Iowa, appreciates that President Donald Trumpâ€™s Justice Department sent a federal hate crimes attorney to aid the prosecution of a man accused of killing the high school student. But Johnson, who is no fan of Trump, wants the administration to push for the legal rights of all LGBTQ people, not just her child.

â€œI love the fact that they have intervened,â€ she told HuffPost in a phone interview. But, â€œit shouldnâ€™t have taken for a child to lose his life, and for everybody to think it was a hate crime, for them to step up and do something,â€ she added, using the male pronoun to refer to Kedarie Johnson. â€œThey need to continue to do something, even after this case is over.â€

Attorney General Jeff Sessions took the unusual step of sending a federal lawyer, Christopher Perras, to help prosecute one of two men charged in the killing of the 16-year-old, The New York Times reported Sunday. The decision surprised people familiar with the case, particularly given that Sessions has rolled back protections for LGBTQ people more broadly. He has, for example, overturned a policy that encourages schools to let transgender students use the bathroom facilities that correspond with their gender identities.

Although several news outlets have referred to Kedarie as transgender, Katrina Johnson and a school mentor prefer the term â€œgender-fluid.â€ Johnson said Kedarie sometimes liked to wear girlâ€™s clothing and go by the name Kandicee, and they would go get their nails and hair done together. But she compared Kedarie to â€œRuPaul,â€ referring to RuPaul Andre Charles, a professional drag queen who is gay and identifies as male. When Kedarie came out to her as being interested in boys, she said, she was supportive, though she said some peers bullied her child.

â€œI had to teach him and instill in him, donâ€™t be ashamed of who you are,â€ she said. â€œBe who you are and what you are, no matter what people think.â€

Shaunda Campbell, former career center coordinator at Burlington Community High School and a mentor to Kedarie, said the teen had a big heart and cared a lot for others. â€œIf he saw somebody crying in the hallways at school, he would always try to go and comfort them,â€ she told HuffPost. â€œHe was comfortable in his own skin; I tell you, I have yet to meet somebody, even an adult, like that.â€

Campbell said she was surprised by the Justice Departmentâ€™s action. â€œBecause heâ€™s a kid, I would hope that something like this would happen and Iâ€™m grateful,â€ she said. â€œBut, thereâ€™s so many people that this has happened to, and if nothing else, Iâ€™m hoping this will get some recognition around the United States that hey, this isnâ€™t okay that people are getting killed because theyâ€™re transgender or gender-fluid or [because of their sexual orientation.]â€

First-degree murder charges have been filed in the case against Jorge Luis Sanders-Galvez, whose trial is scheduled to start next week, and Jaron Narelle Purham, who is being prosecuted separately. (DOJ officials declined to comment on whether Perras is aiding in the prosecution of Purham, for whom a trial date has not been set.)

Though Johnson and others believe Kedarieâ€™s murder was a hate crime, the cases are not being prosecuted as such under Iowa state law. (The statute covers sexual orientation, but not gender identity.)

Federal officials, though, have been investigating whether Sanders-Galvez should be charged with a federal hate crime, â€œand so they would like to be part of the state case for seamless prosecution, should an indictment in federal court be handed down,â€ Amy Beavers, the Des Moines County attorney, told The Des Moines Register. (She did not respond to HuffPost for a request for comment.)

Curtis Dial, a defense attorney who represents Sanders-Galvez, said the Justice Department contacted him in July and informed him of the investigation. â€œI was surprised that there is another attorney joining the prosecution,â€ he told HuffPost. â€œIt doesnâ€™t have any effect on the way that weâ€™re handling our case.â€

Sessions directed civil rights division attorneys to â€œdedicate themselves to proactively investigate a certain set of cases of individuals who were murdered because they are transgender,â€ Devin Oâ€™Malley, a DOJ spokesman, told HuffPost in an email. â€œThis is just one example of the attorney generalâ€™s commitment to enforcing the laws enacted by Congress and to protecting the civil rights of all individuals.â€
TITLE: Mother Of Slain Teen To Trump: Defend All LGBTQ People, Not Just My Child

Although, not all of it. We have a team of over 35 people on the ground, putting in 2,000 man hours to ensure every moment is captured during London Fashion Week--there's a lot going on. Capturing The Theatre Of London Fashion Week SS2017: Days One And Two I've been shooting London Fashion Week for over a decade. I love it. The showmanship and the glamour make it one of the highlights of my year. It's always been so theatrical. Take Vivienne Westwood's most recent Men's London Fashion Week: it was all acrobats - even clowns - and energy. Is #IWWIWWIWI Changing Fashion Week As We Know It? It may not be the most well-known hashtag, but the rise in popularity of the 'I want what I want when I want it' attitude is no secret. Shoppers don't want to fall in love with a dress and have to wait six months for it to be in season and on the rack. As a result, we're seeing the rise of "seasonless fashion" in every market and at every price point. As Director of Retail at Salesforce, Chris works with UK enterprise retail customers to help digitally transform their customer experience

Why Equality On The Runway Needs To Happen Now Now, with the most glitz and glam event in the fashion calendar just around the corner, it's time to scream about diversity, not whisper. In my eyes, the sooner we see a catwalk that is full of a variety of women, the better. Although small steps are undeniably a positive thing, it's time to strive for bigger leaps to be made to include women of every race, age, shape and size. Fashion, beauty and lifestyle blogger.

It transcends ethos and aesthetics and runs deep into the past, through two generations of her family. Her grandmother, a maths and physics professor in her native Russia, who during communist times made clothing on the side for neighbours and friends for extra income, inspired her to pursue a career in art and craft. You are hoping that the winter days will start coming to an end, that your well worn jeans and jumpers will get a break and this summer you will really embrace feminine dressing that you say you will do every year. A Humpback whale has been feeding around us, at the surface of the water, for 45 minutes. Freelance travel & entertainment editor based in London

Chapter 3: Holbox Island "Welcome home", I was told with a smile as I stepped into CasaSandra after a mammoth 20 hour journey from London to Holbox Island and it felt like home. All my worries and apprehension were washed away the moment I walked up the candlelit footpath of the boutique hotel. My Mexican adventure had begun. Presenter, DJ, writer, and secret hopeless romantic

Travel - The Baby Edition Long gone are the days of basking peacefully in the sun on an isolated beach in the Mediterranean, or the indulgent yet meditative afternoon walks down 5th Avenue exercising both legs and credit card Mother and writer.

Why I Hate The Phrase 'Gap Year' The amount of times I've heard people say to me; "do it why you're young", as if the only time that we should open ourselves up to new possibilities is when we're still young enough to enjoy them, before age, and responsibility bears down on us, and we can no longer afford to take a break from our lives. Writer & journalist

48 Hours In... St Lucia Everything about St Lucia is green. From her lushly vegetated peaks undulating across the teardrop shaped island, to her twinkling emerald waters, it's a Caribbean paradise chock-full of geological marvels. Arts, lifestyle and socio-political writer

Traversing The Rockies - Week 4 (D28-30) After 10km, and a river crossing made making us unavoidably wet, we lost the path. Multiple small rivers and bogs had us pretty much soaked. One river crossing had to be made across a log and while Stan managed it with relative ease, I obviously fell off and into fast flowing river up to my hips. Lucy is a London based Doctor setting out to traverse the Canadian Rocky Mountains on the Great Divide Trail- 2 people, 60 days, 1600km.

Is This Ireland's Best Kept Secret? I thought I knew this part of Ireland pretty well until we arrived in Glengarriff and I quickly realised this is a part of my home county I have failed to explore. The view from our hotel upon check in was magical, the soft evening light reflecting on the bay. Irish Travel Blogger. Skyscanner addict.

Traversing The Rockies - Week Four (D25-27) After a warm night, and consequently an abundance of mozzies we started out along the Brazeau River. Expecting torrential rain from Diane's sat phone weather report, we donned our waterproofs at the first raindrops but this proved to be a big mistake with the upcoming climb! Lucy is a London based Doctor setting out to traverse the Canadian Rocky Mountains on the Great Divide Trail- 2 people, 60 days, 1600km.

Chapter 2: Fear And Judgement What I have to regularly remind myself is that people will judge you whether you worry about their opinions or not, so you may as well do what you want to do. Plus, when you think about it, worrying about the opinion of others is actually incredibly self-indulgent because it's based on the assumption that you are important enough to others that they even care about what you're up to. Presenter, DJ, writer, and secret hopeless romantic

Yes, I Take Full Responsibility For This Disease I Can't Control... It has crossed my mind many times that it would be much easier to just not tell people I have epilepsy. But there is always that chance of a seizure, and the risk of something going wrong - or someone doing something wrong - is reduced if we all talk about epilepsy a little bit more and encourage people with epilepsy to do more. If I've decided I can take the risk, you can too. Writer with a tongue-testing name. Condensing the world into frantic words.
TITLE: Travel: Ideas, Advice and Tips On Flights, Hotels And Holidays

Tan dado a los misterios del MÃ¡s AllÃ¡, el escritor ha desvelado el secreto que conduce al MÃ¡s AcÃ¡ que representa la salida del hotel.
Cristina: No, aunque sÃ­ nos habÃ­amos visto una vez cuando Javier presentÃ³ en una librerÃ­a de Madrid un libro de la editorial en la que entonces trabajaba.
Javier: Pues yo a Cristina no la he leÃ­do, pero estoy deseando comenzar la novela por la que le acaban de premiar.
Fue, por cierto, una novela que me hizo fallar a uno de los Premios Planeta.
Me parece tan interesante todo lo que tiene que contar...Â¿Sois conscientes de que el listÃ³n del aÃ±o pasado ha quedado muy alto?
TEXT:
Faltan apenas 15 minutos para que comience la fiesta de los Premios Planeta y Javier Sierra, que tres horas despuÃ©s serÃ¡ designado ganador por El fuego Invisible, estÃ¡ completamente perdido en el hotel.

Vestido de forma impecable, ha acabado desorientado junto a un grupo de otros diez invitados en las entraÃ±as del edificio, repleto de pasillos desiertos y escaleras que llevan a puertas de servicio cerradas.

El hotel se ha convertido en un gran laberinto sin salida al exterior. Hasta que Javier Sierra da un paso al frente y lidera al grupo hacia una puerta que parece clausurada. Empuja y, de golpe, se escuchan voces y se hace la la luz.

Tan dado a los misterios del MÃ¡s AllÃ¡, el escritor ha desvelado el secreto que conduce al MÃ¡s AcÃ¡ que representa la salida del hotel. Responde a las alabanzas de los hasta entonces perdidos con una tÃ­mida sonrisa, la misma que mostrarÃ¡, pocas horas despuÃ©s, cuando los miembros del jurado pronuncien su nombre como ganador de la XLVI ediciÃ³n de los premios Planeta.

Pasado el fervor de la gala, Javier Sierra y Cristina LÃ³pez Barrio, finalista con Niebla en TÃ¡nger, se sientan juntos para El HuffPost en su primera entrevista conjunta. SÃ³lo disponen de diez minutos. Es la 1:45 de la maÃ±ana y los ojos de felicidad empiezan a desfallecer.

Â¿Os conocÃ­ais?

Cristina: No, aunque sÃ­ nos habÃ­amos visto una vez cuando Javier presentÃ³ en una librerÃ­a de Madrid un libro de la editorial en la que entonces trabajaba.

Javier: SÃ­, hemos estado recordando ese dÃ­a, cÃ³mo Cristina me enseÃ±Ã³ no sÃ³lo la librerÃ­a, sino algo insÃ³lito y que yo nunca habÃ­a visto: una trastienda que era como una cocina....

Cristina: Â¡Es cierto! AhÃ­ hacÃ­amos talleres porque la editorial tambiÃ©n tenÃ­a una librerÃ­a y yo ayudaba en la organizaciÃ³n cuando habÃ­a presentaciones. Bueno, ademÃ¡s te habÃ­a visto en la televisiÃ³n mil veces.

Â¿Os habÃ©is leÃ­do?

Javier: Pues yo a Cristina no la he leÃ­do, pero estoy deseando comenzar la novela por la que le acaban de premiar.

Cristina: Yo sÃ­ te he leÃ­do [Risas]. Lo que pasa es que ahora estoy hecha polvo y no me acuerdo... Â¿Se llamaba El Ãngel azul?

Javier: No, El Ãngel perdido. La de Santiago de Compostela que termina en el Monte Ararat.

Cristina: Eso, eso. Me gustÃ³ mucho y me pareciÃ³ fascinante cuando contabas que el Arca de NoÃ© habÃ­a aparecido en lo alto del Monte Ararat.

Javier: SÃ­, debajo de un glaciar.

Cristina: Y luego ademÃ¡s yo estaba leyendo la epopeya de Gilgamesh y todo me cuadraba.

Javier: Es que la resoluciÃ³n de esa novela estÃ¡ en una pilastra del PÃ³rtico de la Gloria que habla tambiÃ©n de Gilgamesh. Fue, por cierto, una novela que me hizo fallar a uno de los Premios Planeta.

Por lo que sabÃ©is hasta ahora de la novela premiada del otro, Â¿tiene un argumento que os interesa?

Cristina: A mÃ­ lo que escribe Javier me interesa mucho, me parece fascinante y me despierta mucha curiosidad. Yo le seguÃ­a tambiÃ©n en la tele, todos los misterios que cuenta, y el Santo Grial es un tema literario por excelencia. Y creo que va mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de lo estrictamente literario. Aparte escribe sobre algo que enlaza un poco con mi novela: la creatividad y el ejercicio de escribir, la escritura creativa... Creo que ahÃ­ nuestras novelas convergen, en hablar de cÃ³mo surge una idea, de lo que supone...

Javier: Cristina ha dicho en su discurso, mientras explicaba el proceso de creaciÃ³n de su novela, que se sentÃ­a como devorada por un fuego.

Cristina: Por una alimaÃ±a.

Javier: Eso. Y yo he dado un salto en la silla porque he pensado: Â¡Si estÃ¡ hablando de mi tema! Me ha encantado.

Â¿EstÃ¡is preparados para pasar los prÃ³ximos meses juntos, de promociÃ³n en promociÃ³n?

Ambos: SÃ­, sÃ­.

Javier: Es un reto interesante. Porque nos vamos a leer, nos vamos a conocer, vamos a compartir muchas veladas.

Cristina: A mÃ­ a lo mejor me va a odiar por las muchas preguntas quÃ© le voy a hacer, estilo 'A ver, Javier, cuÃ©ntame esta historia'. Me parece tan interesante todo lo que tiene que contar...

Â¿Sois conscientes de que el listÃ³n del aÃ±o pasado ha quedado muy alto? Dolores Redondo y Marcos Chicot vendieron mucho y durante muchos meses.

Javier: SÃ­, somos conscientes y muy felices de que haya sido asÃ­ porque eso significa que el premio es algo vivo y que ayuda realmente a vender una novela. Pero creo que cada novela tiene su mundo, su historia, que no estÃ¡ escrita aunque parezca una contradicciÃ³n. El destino de una novela se escribe con cada lector que arriba a ella y a mÃ­ eso me parece interesante. NingÃºn libro es igual a otro, ninguno tiene el mismo destino, el mismo alcance. Me parece muy interesante disfrutar, Cristina con su libro y yo con el mÃ­o, de la vida que va a tener. Es como un niÃ±o, que no sabes quÃ© serÃ¡ de Ã©l.

En la rueda de prensa Javier ha eludido entrar en el tema de la crisis de CataluÃ±a pero, Cristina, a ti no te han preguntado. Â¿CÃ³mo estÃ¡s viviendo la situaciÃ³n actual?

Cristina: Es un momento de tristeza colectiva y, quizÃ¡, de reflexionar un poco sobre algo que lleva muchos aÃ±os latente y que ha estallado. Afecta a la sociedad, a los amigos, a las familias. La pluralidad es cultura, es riqueza. Y, sobre todo, el respeto. En esta sociedad estamos perdiendo el respeto a las opiniones ajenas, parece que tuviÃ©ramos que opinar todos igual, como si fuÃ©ramos mÃ¡quinas. Si la sociedad ha evolucionado ha sido, precisamente, por la pluralidad. El respeto ha quedado atrÃ¡s y deberÃ­a volver. Cada uno tiene derecho a opinar lo que le dÃ© la gana y tÃº debes respetar esa opiniÃ³n.

Javier: Yo lo veo como un reto, es una oportunidad de crecimiento. Estamos en un momento histÃ³rico y es la ocasiÃ³n para demostrarnos que somos un pueblo inteligente. Lo deberÃ­amos superar, si es que lo somos. Si esto falla quiere decir que no hay inteligencia. Mi novela va sobre el poder de las palabras y aquÃ­ la palabra a invocar es Paz. Es una palabra muy poderosa, muy maltratada y muy poco utilizada. Hay otra palabra que es muy importante para resolver esto: amor. Necesitamos mÃ¡s amor porque nos queremos.
TITLE: El primer cara a cara de los ganadores del Premio Planeta 2017

SUMMARY:
In their quest to take over the world and replace human beings, robots were missing one always crucial element - the ability to perform tasks quite as effectively as people do.
Itâ€™s a feature that will make them better at everything from cooking an omelette to dismantling roadside bombs.
Some robots already use fully instrumented fingers but that sense of â€˜touchâ€™ is still limited to that appendage and such skins have not yet provided a full range of tactile information.
And prototypes have shown they are able to measure tactile information with more precision and sensitivity than human skin.
Associate professor Veronica Santos, says: â€œThe fact that our latest skin prototype incorporates all three modalities creates many new possibilities for machine learning-based approaches for advancing robot capabilities.â€
TEXT:
In their quest to take over the world and replace human beings, robots were missing one always crucial element - the ability to perform tasks quite as effectively as people do.

But now all that has changed.

A team of robotics engineers in the USA have made an â€œimportant breakthroughâ€ in developing a flexible skin that allows machines to feel what they are doing (and when it is going wrong) so they can rectify the situation.

Itâ€™s a feature that will make them better at everything from cooking an omelette to dismantling roadside bombs.

UCLA Engineering

In order for robots to perform delicate tasks, such as cooking, housework, or surgery, they need to know whether a small or delicate object is slipping out of their grasp.

Jonathan Posner, a senior author on the study, said: â€œIf a robot is going to dismantle an improvised explosive device, it needs to know whether itâ€™s hand is sliding along a wire or pulling on it. Or to hold on to a medical instrument, it needs to know if the object is slipping.â€

To date it has been impossible for robotic hands to accurately sense the vibrations and forces that occur, for example, when an object is starting to fall.

Some robots already use fully instrumented fingers but that sense of â€˜touchâ€™ is still limited to that appendage and such skins have not yet provided a full range of tactile information.

But the team from the University of Washington have now created a bio-inspired skin that can be stretched over any part of a robot, or prosthetic, to successfully grasp and manipulate objects in everyday tasks.

This is a giant step forward in the effective application real-world of robotics.

The skin, manufactured at the nanofabrication facility, is made from the same silicone rubber used in swimming goggles and embedded with tiny serpentine channels that are roughly half the width of a human hair.

These channels are filled with electronically conductive liquid metal, which wonâ€™t crack or fatigue as solid wires do.

And prototypes have shown they are able to measure tactile information with more precision and sensitivity than human skin.

This development is so important because it will allow robots in the future to open doors, interact with a phone, shake hands, pick up packages, and handle objects, among many other things.

Associate professor Veronica Santos, says: â€œThe fact that our latest skin prototype incorporates all three modalities creates many new possibilities for machine learning-based approaches for advancing robot capabilities.â€
TITLE: This Flexible Skin Can Actually Give Robots A Real Sense Of 'Touch'

SUMMARY:
Sydney's Central Station became a battleground on Tuesday night, with a dramatic staged police operation involving violent terrorist gunmen.
The major training exercise -- called Exercise Pantograph -- involved 160 personnel from the NSW Police Force, Transport for NSW, Fire & Rescue NSW and Ambulance NSW and was inspired by recent terror attacks in London.
Exercise Pantograph: Central Railway Station Active Armed Offender Exercise.
The Active Armed Offender exercise was not the result of any threat, Police said, but rather a vital component of the ongoing training program.
Exercise Pantograph was an Australia New Zealand Counter Terrorism Committee funded exercise.
TEXT:
An image of one of the actors playing a gunman at Central Station.

Sydney's Central Station became a battleground on Tuesday night, with a dramatic staged police operation involving violent terrorist gunmen.

The major training exercise -- called Exercise Pantograph -- involved 160 personnel from the NSW Police Force, Transport for NSW, Fire & Rescue NSW and Ambulance NSW and was inspired by recent terror attacks in London.

"Recent incidents such as the attack on London Bridge and the Borough Market, and the attacks at the Bataclan theatre in Paris, have shown us that armed terrorists, can strike anywhere at any time," Commander of the Counter Terrorism and Special Tactics Command, Assistant Commissioner Mark Murdoch said in a statement.

"As first responders, we have to be able to deal with situations with strength and surety."

In video supplied by the police, the terrorists shoot and stab their way through Central Railway station as police and other staff respond in real-time.

"The Active Armed Offender program has been designed specifically to equip officers with the additional skills, training and resources they need when first on the scene at a terrorism or high-risk incident," Assistant Commissioner Murdoch said.

Exercise Pantograph: Central Railway Station Active Armed Offender Exercise. https://t.co/NtNIsvJlf9 pic.twitter.com/xdtqBHzUIL â€” NSW Police (@nswpolice) October 18, 2017

"Whilst I can't go into the exact methodology, it's fair to say this type of training is more dynamic and fluid than regular Police firearms training."

The Active Armed Offender exercise was not the result of any threat, Police said, but rather a vital component of the ongoing training program.

Exercise Pantograph was an Australia New Zealand Counter Terrorism Committee funded exercise.

Owners and operators of Crowded Places are encouraged to go to the Useful Resources section on the secureNSW website where they will find a range of guidance material to help protect crowded from terrorism. www.secure.nsw.gov.au/useful-resources
TITLE: Watch: NSW Police Anti-Terror Exercise Shows How An Attack Would Go Down

SUMMARY:
Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has become the second state leader in as many months to throw his support behind a movement urging Australian states and territories to ban the retail use of plastic bags, announcing a statewide ban on single-use plastic bags on Tuesday.
"I have been convinced by ['The Project's] advocacy over such a consistent amount of time to announce... that Victoria will ban single-use plastic bags," he said.
"Victoria will ban single use plastic bags, we know this is really important for the environment!"
Victoria to ban single use plastic bags!!
Correction: An earlier version of this story stated that Australians dispose of 4 million plastic bags a year.
TEXT:
Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has become the second state leader in as many months to throw his support behind a movement urging Australian states and territories to ban the retail use of plastic bags, announcing a statewide ban on single-use plastic bags on Tuesday.

Responding to mounting pressure in light of a Change.org petition launched by Channel Ten's 'The Project' in April in collaboration with Clean Up Australia, Andrews said he has finally been convinced to make the move -- which he said is important for Victoria's "waterways, for landfill [and] for waste management".

"I have been convinced by ['The Project's] advocacy over such a consistent amount of time to announce... that Victoria will ban single-use plastic bags," he said.

"We know this is really important for the environment, particularly for our waterways, for landfill, for waste management.

"The Minister for the Environment [Lily D'Ambrosio] will have more to say about that tomorrow and we will get this done as quickly as we can."

"Victoria will ban single use plastic bags, we know this is really important for the environment!" Thanks @DanielAndrewsMP for stepping up to #BanTheBag! ğŸ”” #auspol #TheProjectTV pic.twitter.com/1llr00QKOB â€” The Project (@theprojecttv) October 17, 2017

As of this year, South Australia, Tasmania, the Northern Territory and the ACT all have bans on plastic bags in place, with Queensland set to join them in 2018. In light of this, the original petition challenged Western Australia's Premier Mark McGowan, NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian and Andrews to match those states in banning the bags.

Hooray! Victoria to ban single use plastic bags!! Welcome to 2017 Premier!!! #TheProjectTV â€” Kassandra Hall ğŸŒˆ (@khalllaw) October 17, 2017

In September, McGowan became the first of the trio to take up the challenge and announce a ban on plastic bags after being convinced by letters sent to him from young Western Australian students.

"I've always had the view we should get rid of more plastics and clearly young people support it and I had a lot of letters from kids from local schools who are very supportive," he said at the time.

"It is good for the environment, it saves marine life and wildlife. I am a strong conservationist so anything that does that, has my support."

"I'd encourage NSW and VIC to follow WAs lead, they normally do!" @MarkMcGowanMP talks about his decision to #BanTheBag! #TheProjectTV pic.twitter.com/kzPaV7l6xo â€” The Project (@theprojecttv) September 12, 2017

According to Clean Up Australia, Australians dispose of an estimated 4 billion plastic bags, or more than 20,000 tonnes of plastic waste, each year. Only three percent of these are recycled, with the rest finding their way into the environment or landfill.

Both McGowan's and Andrews' announcements also come after Australia's two biggest supermarket giants, Woolworth and Coles, both announced plans in July to phase out single-use plastic bags over the next twelve months.

And so the focus now turns to Berejiklian to see whether she will match her interstate counterparts in signing her name to a statewide ban on plastic bags in NSW -- Australia's most populous state.

Correction: An earlier version of this story stated that Australians dispose of 4 million plastic bags a year. This is in fact 4 billion.
TITLE: Victoria Just Announced It Will Ban Single-Use Plastic Bags

The Football Association (FA) has apologised to two England women football players after new evidence showed that a former manager made remarks that were â€œdiscriminatory on the grounds of raceâ€.
It has been found that on two separate occasions Mark Sampson made â€œill-judged attempts at humourâ€ towards players Eniola Aluko and Drew Spence.
Martin Glenn, chief executive of the FA, said in a statement: â€œOn behalf of The Football Association I would like to sincerely apologise to Eniola Aluko and Drew Spence.
This is not acceptable.â€Despite Newton concluding that Sampson made poorly-judged attempts at humour, she said he â€œwas not a racistâ€.
Sampson was sacked last month as England Womenâ€™s head coach over â€œinappropriate and unacceptable behaviourâ€ in a previous role.
TEXT:
The Football Association (FA) has apologised to two England women football players after new evidence showed that a former manager made remarks that were â€œdiscriminatory on the grounds of raceâ€.

It has been found that on two separate occasions Mark Sampson made â€œill-judged attempts at humourâ€ towards players Eniola Aluko and Drew Spence.

The FAâ€™s apology came just as a parliamentary inquiry was beginning in London with senior officials facing questions over the investigations into Sampsonâ€™s alleged racism and bullying of Aluko.

Sky News Eniola Aluko.

Aluko told a committee of MPs on Wednesday that the FAâ€™s treatment of her was â€œbordering on blackmailâ€.

Her comments came after she said that she had not received payment of an Â£80,000 settlement fee in full from the FA.

â€œI had one meeting with Martin Glenn and he effectively suggested that if I wrote a favourable statement saying that the FA are not institutionally racist that they would think about releasing that money. I felt that was bordering on blackmail,â€ Aluko said.

â€œFor Martin Glenn to effectively suggest that I should say that the FA are not institutionally racist in order to get a payment that they already contractually agreed to, I think is, again, a suggestion that the case has been handled appallingly.

PA Wire/PA Images Mark Sampson.

Martin Glenn, chief executive of the FA, said in a statement: â€œOn behalf of The Football Association I would like to sincerely apologise to Eniola Aluko and Drew Spence.

â€œBased on new evidence submitted to independent barrister Katharine Newton, she has now found that they were both subject to discriminatory remarks made by an FA employee. This is not acceptable.â€

Despite Newton concluding that Sampson made poorly-judged attempts at humour, she said he â€œwas not a racistâ€.

The statement continued: â€œOur ambition has always been to find the truth and take swift and appropriate action if needed.

â€œIt was our decision to have the original, second and final investigation to ensure that due diligence was taken.

â€œIt is regrettable that Eniola did not participate in the first externale investigation as this would have enabled Katharine Newton to conduct and complete her investigation sooner.

â€œWe fully support the recommendations from the report.â€

FA statement from Martin Glenn pic.twitter.com/mLvexO8R2T â€” FA Spokesperson (@FAspokesperson) October 18, 2017

Aluko, an experienced international, had claimed that Sampson had told her to be careful that her Nigerian relatives did not bring the Ebola virus with them when they came to watch a game at Wembley.

Aluko, who has been capped 102 times for England, has not played since making her claims last year.

The 30-year-old said she had suffered â€œvictimisationâ€ for speaking out about discrimination in the England team set-up.

She received around Â£80,000 ($105,376) from the FA, which said the settlement was to avoid the threat of an employment tribunal disrupting the England womenâ€™s teamâ€™s preparations for this yearâ€™s European Championships.

Spence, a mixed-race player, alleged that after being called up to the England team in 2015 she was asked by Sampson how many times she had been arrested.

Sampson was sacked last month as England Womenâ€™s head coach over â€œinappropriate and unacceptable behaviourâ€ in a previous role.

Tracey Crouch, the Sport Minister, said at the time that the situation was â€œa messâ€ and â€œraises very serious questionsâ€ about the FAâ€™s recruitment process.
TITLE: Mark Sampson Case: FA Apologises To Eniola Aluko And Drew Spence Over Former Manager's 'Discriminatory' And Racial Remarks

SUMMARY:
As the nation woke up to news that Tragically Hip frontman Gord Downie died from brain cancer Tuesday night, tributes for the beloved Canadian icon began pouring in across social media.
Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and comedian Rick Mercer were just a few of the notable public figures and everyday fans who expressed their condolences.
pic.twitter.com/igl5dOqNAs â€” Sunnybrook Hospital (@Sunnybrook) October 18, 2017His loss was felt especially in Kingston, Ont., where the band was formed in 1983.
#RIPGord #ygk pic.twitter.com/UCCQ2LaH7V â€” Richelle Morgan (@richellejmorgan) October 18, 2017The singer had been diagnosed with gliobastoma, an aggressive form of brain cancer, in 2015.
The Tragically Hip officially announced Downie's illness in May 2016, just before they started their final tour.
TEXT:
As the nation woke up to news that Tragically Hip frontman Gord Downie died from brain cancer Tuesday night, tributes for the beloved Canadian icon began pouring in across social media.

The band posted a statement announcing Downie's death early Wednesday.

In less than two hours, #TragicallyHip, #RIPGord, and #RIPGordDownie were already top trending hashtags on Twitter.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and comedian Rick Mercer were just a few of the notable public figures and everyday fans who expressed their condolences.

There will never be another one like you, Gord. Rest in peace my friend. â€” Justin Trudeau (@JustinTrudeau) October 18, 2017

What a gift Gord was to all of us. The country feels gutted right now. #RipGord #Poets â€” Rick Mercer (@rickmercer) October 18, 2017

I am in Algiers but my heart is back home - just heard the news thinking of #Gord playing Fidder's Green on my phone https://t.co/dqOdrNbZkH â€” Paul Dewar (@PaulDewar) October 18, 2017

Gord Downie's legacy extends beyond his music. He raised unprecedented awareness for glioblastoma. Our condolences to his family & friends. pic.twitter.com/igl5dOqNAs â€” Sunnybrook Hospital (@Sunnybrook) October 18, 2017

His loss was felt especially in Kingston, Ont., where the band was formed in 1983.

We are playing non stop Hip all day. If you would like to hear something specific, or have a story about Gord, call us at 613-545-1057 #YGK â€” K-Rock 105.7 (@Krock1057) October 18, 2017

Stopped by here to pay respect this morning while downtown Kingston. #RIPGord #ygk pic.twitter.com/UCCQ2LaH7V â€” Richelle Morgan (@richellejmorgan) October 18, 2017

The singer had been diagnosed with gliobastoma, an aggressive form of brain cancer, in 2015. The Tragically Hip officially announced Downie's illness in May 2016, just before they started their final tour.
TITLE: Fans 'Gutted' As Tributes Pour In For Tragically Hip Frontman Gord Downie

SUMMARY:
Author and insight specialistMy Children Are Too Much For Me I have two children and I am done making babies.
For a parent, there are few things as fun as helping your child transform themselves into their favourite character.
David is Retail Products Policy Adviser at the British Retail ConsortiumAdopting Siblings Has Changed Our Lives - Let's Celebrate The Joy Of Adoption This National Adoption Week Adoption is hard, and nothing truly prepares you for some of the challenges that come with it.
Adoptive Mum to two fabulous girls, tired, optimistic, happyRaising Feminist Sons I know how to raise a strong woman because I am one.
SEND Blogger, Lecturer, Writer and (possibly most importantly) Autism Parent
TEXT:
#MeToo: Why We Need To Talk To Our Children About The Harvey Weinstein Case Yesterday, I - like thousands of other women around the world - shared my experience of sexual abuse on social media, under the #MeToo hashtag. This was in response to a tweet by actress Alyssa Milano, urging people to post the words 'me too' if they had ever been sexually harassed or assaulted. Author and insight specialist

My Children Are Too Much For Me I have two children and I am done making babies. I know this with no shadow of a doubt. Give me a newborn and I will coo and cluck and savour those cuddles, but I won't hand them back and feel a hole that another baby needs to fill. My two kids are enough for me. Some days my children are too much for me! Blogs at lifeloveanddirtydishes.com

Expecting, But Not Sure When... This week is National Adoption Week, and given that my wonderful husband and I have very recently been approved as adopters I wanted to write a bit about why we have decided to adopt, what it means for us and our family, and explain the process for anyone who might be considering it. Lover of shiny things, music and life.

Parenting Is Hard When You Aren't On The Same Page When we fell pregnant it obviously opened us up to having some raw and honest conversations. For example... what sort of parents did we want to be? How would we raise our daughter? What was really important to us? What values did we want to instil in this tiny human we would be responsible for crafting? mother, woman and business owner

Setting The Standard On The Safety Of Children's Dress-up Dressing up as a superhero or a monster is one of the great joys of growing up, especially at Halloween. For a parent, there are few things as fun as helping your child transform themselves into their favourite character. Whilst accessories and make-up can take you so far; the most important thing is a great costume. David is Retail Products Policy Adviser at the British Retail Consortium

Adopting Siblings Has Changed Our Lives - Let's Celebrate The Joy Of Adoption This National Adoption Week Adoption is hard, and nothing truly prepares you for some of the challenges that come with it. But they also don't prepare you for how wonderful it is. We have become a real team together, and there is really nothing sweeter than seeing our two girls grow together as siblings, build these strong bonds and grow into these beautiful little girls - our beautiful little girls. Adoptive Mum to two fabulous girls, tired, optimistic, happy

Raising Feminist Sons I know how to raise a strong woman because I am one. Raising a compassionate son who doesn't abuse his male privilege, who understands it, is the trickier prospect. Thankfully, I have a grown-up one of those in the house to help on this journey. Irresponsibly hanging out in Mexico with small kids and blogging about it.

Thinking Outside The Neurotypical Box What my son has taught me is that there is no such thing as normal and abnormal, just ordinary and extraordinary - and people on the spectrum have a lateral, literal, tangential logic which is truly original and fascinating. Author, ambassador for the National Autistic Society

Why Have The Number Of Home Births Dropped? Our maternity services are seeing women with more complicated pregnancies than we have had before. Factors including rising levels of obesity and higher numbers of older women giving birth all mean that our services need to ensure these women get the safest possible care and attention. RCMâ€™s Director for England

The Science Of Safer Pregnancy: How Mini 'Placentas On A Chip' May Help Us Understand Pre-eclampsia The placenta is the gatekeeper for a foetus, allowing a mother's nutrients to pass in one direction while waste passes back into the mother's bloodstream. It produces hormones to encourage foetal growth and offers protection against most bacteria, although not against viruses. Post-doctoral scientist, cardiovascular specialist, with experience in both industry and academia

Seven Things To Learn From Tech Execs Who Limit Their Kids' Tech Usage Tech executives know all the ins and outs of online world, and this is why they know what to allow, and where to safeguard their kids. Technology is a different reality, and just as you are showing them how the real world works, so you should be doing with the virtual one. Coach, author of Homo Distractus, founder of Consciously Digital

What To Do When Your Toddler Is Impatient When you first have a child it is human nature to put their needs above all else. I remember feeling like there was nothing more important than my baby. He needed feeding, I would feed on demand. He needed cuddling and comforting, I would drop everything and make sure he knew I was there. Blogger / Former Fashion Buyer

I Had Cervical Cancer, Now I Think All Teenagers Should Have The Opportunity To Find Out How They Can Reduce Their Risk I sat her down and asked again if she knew what the HPV vaccine was for and why it would be important for her to have it. Of course she didn't, as she hadn't learned anything about HPV and its connection to cervical cancer. Supporter of Joâ€™s Cervical Cancer Trust

Why I'll Never Judge That Mum Who Has Her Kids Out Shopping At Midnight It was the 23rd of December 2012. My family--myself, my then-husband, and our two children were living paycheck to paycheck. No, worse than that; we were living paycheck to almost-paycheck. Anyone who has ever struggled will know how hard those last few days before payday can be. A place to share knowledge and better understand the world

You Don't Need To Shield Your Kids From My Autistic Children You see, I've already seen the look when people are afraid of us. I've seen the wide birth with the eyes of horror. I've seen parents pull their kids away from our family. Not when anything serious has been happening, just when David has maybe been squealing or jumping about. Or when Anthony has been skipping a bit erratically. SEND Blogger, Lecturer, Writer and (possibly most importantly) Autism Parent
TITLE: Parent Voices
