SUMMARY:
It's never been a more exciting time for small food businesses and startups.
With niches and food specialities emerging every day -- whether it's whole foods, vegan food, superfoods or sustainable food -- there's room for food entrepreneurs and companies to sprout and fill the gaps.
Enter Chobani's Food Incubator program which Aussie food startups with big ideas can now apply.
What's involved in the Food Incubator program?
The Food Incubator program aims to unearth and nurture innovative food start-ups who will challenge the system and shape the future of the Australian food industry.
TEXT:
Chobani is looking for small businesses to bring new delicious, nutritious foods to Australians.

It's never been a more exciting time for small food businesses and startups. With niches and food specialities emerging every day -- whether it's whole foods, vegan food, superfoods or sustainable food -- there's room for food entrepreneurs and companies to sprout and fill the gaps.

But getting your product on the market and building a brand isn't easy. Not only is it expensive, but often startups don't have the resources to support product development, quality and marketing.

Enter Chobani's Food Incubator program which Aussie food startups with big ideas can now apply.

Partnering with Monash University's Food Innovation Centre, the Chobani Food Incubator will combine Monash's facilities to support new product development, innovation and quality with Chobani's expertise in sales, marketing and customer engagement. Plus you'll get $10,000 capital -- no strings attached.

"At Chobani one of our values is giving back," managing director of Chobani Australia Peter Meek told HuffPost Australia.

"We started the program in the U.S almost 18 months ago and in Australia we've got a slightly different program in that we're partnering with Monash University, specifically the Food Innovation Centre. This gives us broader capability and resources to help food startups.

"We're really excited to share what we've learned and we're hoping to make a great difference to the food industry via these startups, and have fun doing it."

What do you need to apply?

"You basically just apply on the website, which closes at the end of November, and the winners will begin the program in February 2018 until April," Meek said.

"The program is for people who are further on than just an idea: they have already started, have a product or concept, and most importantly have the passion and drive to make it bigger. This is the critical thing.

"It's hard work creating something from scratch but hopefully with support from us we can increase their chances for success, bigger and faster."

Essentially, if you've got a product but don't know how to take your product or business to the next level, the Food Incubator program is for you.

"This is the biggest challenge for small business and it was our biggest challenge," Meek said. "There are lots of entrepreneurs with great ideas but it's quite hard to take it to the next level. We want to share what we've learned to help other businesses do the same."

What's involved in the Food Incubator program?

The Food Incubator program aims to unearth and nurture innovative food start-ups who will challenge the system and shape the future of the Australian food industry.

The program specifically includes:

4-month incubator from February to April 2018, online and on-site

1-2 team members participating on-site with key Chobani team members

Monthly programs at Chobani locations, including manufacturing facilities and Monash's Food Innovation Centre

Equity-free capital: $10,000 grant to help grow your business

Travel, hotel and other expenses covered

Access to Chobani teams, top executive and experts

"We're here to support them through all the stages of the program, from product development and quality assistance, through to sales and marketing to build your brand -- pretty much all the areas where big businesses often have a scaled advantage over small businesses," Meek said.

"We've learned from experience how you can compete with the big guys with a fraction of the resources if you're smart with where you invest your time and effort.

"We think it's never been a better time for small businesses to bring delicious, nutritious foods to Australians because the landscape has changed in terms of how consumers discover brands."

Entries close on 30 November 2017. Applications can now be submitted here.
TITLE: Have A Food Startup? This Program Helps You Get Going

TEXT:
En conferencia de prensa con medios internacionales, el presidente de Venezuela NicolÃ¡s Maduro se quejÃ³ de la supuesta censura en Facebook e Instagram. Maduro pidiÃ³ reunirse con los directores de la empresa en el paÃ­s y asegurÃ³ que la naciÃ³n se encuentra en una "nueva guerra" que "mÃ¡s temprano que tarde" ganarÃ¡.

"Yo quiero citar a los responsables de Instagram, porque Â¿por quÃ© nos vetan?, Â¿por quÃ© vetan al presidente?", reclamÃ³ Maduro ante medios de comunicaciÃ³n. ExplicÃ³ que al publicar en las redes sociales videos de "informaciÃ³n relevante" la red social no le permite publicitarlos, sin embargo, Ã©l sÃ­ recibe publicidad de otras cuentas.

"Plomo, plomo, plomo y no me puedo defender", exclamÃ³. "Y me meten retardadores para sacarme seguidores o para que no les lleguen mis videos o mi verdad".

El presidente de Venezuela asegurÃ³ que esa es una "nueva guerra" que el paÃ­s enfrenta y que es su deber como gobernante defender al pueblo. PidiÃ³ a su vicepresidente, Tareck El Aissami, investigar quiÃ©nes son los directivos de las redes sociales para citarlos y asegurÃ³ que la prÃ³xima semana tienen "una sorpresita preparada".

#EnVideo ğŸ“¹| Ejecutivo Nacional citarÃ¡ a responsables de Facebook e Instagram en Venezuela por censurar al Presidente NicolÃ¡s Maduro pic.twitter.com/kMzxQW29R4 â€” VTV CANAL 8 (@VTVcanal8) October 17, 2017

Esta no es la primera vez que el presidente de Venezuela se queja del manejo de las redes sociales en su paÃ­s y la supuesta censura hacia su persona. El fin de semana en un evento con empleados de las empresas de telecomunicaciÃ³n estatal, Maduro tambiÃ©n denunciÃ³ la censura en estas plataformas.

"Me tienen vetado en Facebook, en Twitter, en Instagram, utilizan esas herramientas solo para destruir la revoluciÃ³n, se las facilitan, se las regalan [a la oposiciÃ³n], pero para transmitir el mensaje de la revoluciÃ³n, de la patria, de la independencia, del socialismo,no estamos vetados.", explicÃ³

DÃ­as antes, Maduro presentÃ³ la Ley Contra los Delitos de Odio, Intolerancia y Violencia ante la Asamblea Nacional Constituyente la cual se ocuparÃ­a, entre otras cosas, de los contenidos que se escriben y comparten en las redes sociales.
TITLE: NicolÃ¡s Maduro le declara la guerra a Instagram y Facebook

SUMMARY:
Americans spend one third of their lives in bed, but as a nation, we still arenâ€™t getting enough sleep.
As a result of chronic under-rest, our wellbeing is eroding.
To bring awareness -- and solutions -- to this public health issue, The Huffington Post has partnered with Sleep NumberÂ® to present Sleep + Wellness, an editorial section dedicated to empowering readers to live their best, healthiest lives by gaining a better understanding of sleep as a crucial pillar of our well-being.
By taking an all-encompassing, personalized approach to wellness, and educating readers on how sleep connects to fitness, work-life balance, and more, Sleep + Wellness aims to take the stress out of sleep, for good.
To contribute, please email sleeppluswellness@huffingtonpost.com.

TEXT:
Make Mind Care Your Priority I recently set myself a challenge. Instead of just snapping selfies and pictures randomly I would take a photograph everyday of something that made me happy and grateful. It didn't have to be a staged photograph or something for anybody else to see - just a moment that struck a chord and really made me feel something. Parent, teacher, blogger.

Communications and public affairs officer at Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) England

Working With An Eating Disorder And Working Towards Recovery Shouldn't Be In Conflict Just as managing work can be extremely difficult and stressful, living with an eating disorder can be highly taxing. Over the years when I suffered with anorexia, I was so preoccupied with avoiding food, compulsively exercising and abusing laxatives in order to lose weight that my eating disorder eventually became much more important and time-consuming than work. Volunteer with eating disorders and mental health services. Campaigner from lived experience.

The Power Of The Olive Branch C'mon let's be honest here - do you take umbrage? Are you a serious sulker, a wild wound-licker or a door-slammer and throw-away-the-key-er? I'm no slouch when it comes to the flounce, a twist on the heel and nose in the air sharp exit in a flurry of talc and sequins; it feels so good at the time. Life Coach, Author, Columnist

We Need To Teach Kids How To Look After Their Mental Health We've never been taught to put our mental health first in the same way we've been taught to look after and listen to our bodies. This is simply ludicrous and irresponsible. As you're growing up, you're taught to try and reduce the risk of getting sick. Twenty-something aspiring writer. Lover of tea, animals and winter.

Where Do You Get Your Energy From? I am not talking about your utility provider, but your personal energy supply. If you are thinking along the lines of food, sleep, etc. this isn't what I mean either. I want to talk about the benefits of clean energy; inspiration and appreciation. Writer, Researcher & PR Professional

But being a junior doctor working night-shifts in my late 20s, was the first time I realised the link between sleep and how it affects my health and the way I feel. Doctor, GP, media personality and fitness expert

In its 350-year history, Cliveden has hosted every British monarch since George I and is most famous as the home of the Astors and the setting for the scandal of the Profumo Affair. Reviews and recommendations of handpicked luxury spa hotels, resorts and wellness retreats around the globe.

Also known as Happyologist, helps individuals, teams and organisations find their best performance through helping them become more passionate, positive and proactive

Making Space When I returned from my summer holiday a couple of weeks ago, like many others, I felt relaxed and refreshed - but already the usual stresses are threatening to kick in! International Talent executive

Ten Benefits To Strength Training The history of strength training has been around for decades, however schools of thought still believe it may be harmful for you (although this is changing for the better as science gets more advanced.) Contrary to the belief that weight training is bad for you, there are many benefits in which you could reap from following a well-structured and applied resistance-training plan. Below are 10 reasons why weight training is amazing for you... Co-director of More Than Muscle. I have a passion for all things coaching, educating and fitness writing. www.morethanmuscle.co.uk

Who Do You Trust? In a world of so many opinions, possibilities and 'right' ways to live, decision making can feel overwhelming. We've all been faced with choices - some 'small' and others that feel much more 'important' - should we say yes to that social engagement, do we speak out for what feels 'right', do we turn down that job that doesn't feel right but would say goodbye to financial worries? Transformational Coaching - Evolving you in your Everyday

SUMMARY:
A global suit company for women has stirred controversy with its new advertisements showing fully-clothed women alongside completely naked men.
The Dutch company Suistudio, which launched in August, has included the naked men in a number of different poses -- often with women looming over them.
#SUISTUDIO #NOTDRESSINGMEN A post shared by SUISTUDIO (@suistudio) on Aug 23, 2017 at 1:55am PDTSo are the advertisements objectifying men?
We like naked men and I'm pretty sure there are lots of women that like them too."
"Labelling [the Suistudio woman] as flipping a gender puts too much emphasis on flawed impositions that have been put on the sexes for far too long.
TEXT:
A global suit company for women has stirred controversy with its new advertisements showing fully-clothed women alongside completely naked men.

The Dutch company Suistudio, which launched in August, has included the naked men in a number of different poses -- often with women looming over them.

One pose shows a women in one of Suistudio's designer suits sitting on a couch, with her feet resting on a naked male model's body.

In the Buff. It's time to go nude. #SUISTUDIO #NOTDRESSINGMEN #womeninbusiness #officewear A post shared by SUISTUDIO (@suistudio) on Sep 18, 2017 at 7:10am PDT



Another shows a fully-clothed woman posing with her hand on a male model's behind.

Browse our latest collection online now. We specialise in suits, but we're not dressing men. #SUISTUDIO #NOTDRESSINGMEN A post shared by SUISTUDIO (@suistudio) on Aug 23, 2017 at 1:55am PDT

So are the advertisements objectifying men?

Vice president of Suistudio Kristina Barricelli doesn't think so.

"The problem is in recent history, we haven't seen men objectified in the background. How strange! If you're in the beverage business, you objectify thirst," she told Hindustan Times.



"The moment you take an image and photograph it, it becomes an object. We like naked men and I'm pretty sure there are lots of women that like them too."

However, there has been some negative reaction online too.

@SUISTUDIO_ Amazingly sexist campaign. Just goes to show women now can do anything ... and get away with it!! â€” Jay P (@merakoinahin) October 15, 2017

Suitstudio's CEO Fokke de Jong wrote in a statement that this wasn't just a simple role reversal exercise.

"Labelling [the Suistudio woman] as flipping a gender puts too much emphasis on flawed impositions that have been put on the sexes for far too long. She is powerful, confident, and proud of herself."



"She also has a naked man in her apartment".

Is th
TITLE: Is This Advertising Campaign With Naked Men Sexist?

TITLE: Fitspiration

SUMMARY:
Most of us are unwittingly loading products into our shopping trolleys that have been produced by people in slavery.
It's my firm belief that celebrating and promoting those identified as having learning disabilities impacts positively on society as a whole.
Hearing health advocate, writer, LivingWithHearingLoss.comBeing A Daddy And Campaigning For Shared Parental Leave With our second baby on the way we looked closely, and very excitedly, at the shared parental leave situation, and set about doing our sums.
Campaigner for shared parental leave.
No, not international David Gandy appreciation week....It was National Eye Health Week!
TEXT:
Nine Everyday Products You Never Knew Were Made By Slaves Slavery still exists. In fact, there are more people in slavery today than at any other point in history. And it's not a distant problem that doesn't affect us. Most of us are unwittingly loading products into our shopping trolleys that have been produced by people in slavery. Communications Director at anti-slavery organisation International Justice Mission UK

It's Time For Everyone To See Themselves Represented, Both Onstage And Off. Loud, Proud And Full Of Joy. It's my firm belief that celebrating and promoting those identified as having learning disabilities impacts positively on society as a whole. It's about celebrating difference and the many different ways of being successful and valuable. Playwright and performer with an interest in new perspectives, new narratives, contemporary drama and feminism.

My Life As A Midwife On A Rescue Ship During The Mediterranean Migrant Crisis Alice Gautreau is a midwife working with Medecins Sans Frontieres. In this exclusive vlog for HuffPost UK, Alice talks about her life-saving work on board the Aquarius refugee rescue vessel in the Mediterranean, and the incredible story of helping a woman give birth on board the ship. Medecins sans Frontiere midwife

Making Peace With My Hearing Loss "You have something in your ear," a small voice piped up from behind me at the playground. I heard the voice, but wasn't sure she was talking to me. "Excuse me," she repeated with some alarm, "do you know you have something in your ear?" She was pointing at my ears with surprise. Hearing health advocate, writer, LivingWithHearingLoss.com

Being A Daddy And Campaigning For Shared Parental Leave With our second baby on the way we looked closely, and very excitedly, at the shared parental leave situation, and set about doing our sums. Maybe I could take four months, and my partner take five, and we overlap in the middle? Maybe we could both be off for a chunk of time and make it work? Nope. Campaigner for shared parental leave. Arts professional. Father to Jack.

Prevention Rather Than Cure. Part One... Last week was my favourite week of the year people...no not Christmas. Guess again?! No, not international David Gandy appreciation week....It was National Eye Health Week! Finally, we get a week to preach about looking after your eyes so you don't end up with squiffy ones like mine. Comedian and writer.

What To Expect When You Are (Not) Expecting A Child With Cerebral Palsy William needs 24/7 care, but he loves being with people, whether they are children or 'grown-ups'. If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting the feelings of relief, comfort and happiness when you see them build relationships with adults who want to help them as much as you do. Writer & Disability Campaigner

Life In A Wheelchair - The Questions You Always Wanted To Ask Naturally as a newly injured child, my thoughts didn't turn to mortgages or whether I would be able to get a job. At that time, I had no concept of just how expensive having a spinal cord injury could be. I had far more pressing concerns such as: Head of Bolt Burdon Kemp's spinal injury department

After The Tsunami Hit Thailand In 2004 I Couldn't Leave Those In Need Behind Every evening I taught art to the children on the camp, their drawings were harrowing and therapeutic at the same time. Their pictures initially were of bodies in water and people stuck up trees but soon evolved into happier scenes of elephants rescuing people, and families in their tents smiling. Founder of Acorn Overseas

Yes, I Take Full Responsibility For This Disease I Can't Control... It has crossed my mind many times that it would be much easier to just not tell people I have epilepsy. But there is always that chance of a seizure, and the risk of something going wrong - or someone doing something wrong - is reduced if we all talk about epilepsy a little bit more and encourage people with epilepsy to do more. If I've decided I can take the risk, you can too. Writer with a tongue-testing name. Condensing the world into frantic words.

Are Disabled Young People Being Set Up To Fail? The political party conference season is getting in full swing. Housing, the NHS, social care as well as Brexit are among issues prominent on the agendas at these annual political melting pots. But there's another one which deserves a higher level of attention and that impacts on hundreds of thousands of lives every day in the UK. CEO of Leonard Cheshire Disability. Previously managing director at RNIB Solutions. He is also a co-founder and trustee of Blind in Business.

People Think It's Extraordinary That I Work - But Disability Doesn't Have To Be A Barrier When I graduated from university in 2015, I was under the illusion that with a good degree and a strong CV due to all the volunteering that I'd done, I would find a job pretty quickly. This couldn't have been further from the truth. supporter Scope and Virgin Mediaâ€™s Work With Me campaign

Why Mexico Is Proof Anti-Abortion Laws Don't Work Since January, following President Trump's reintroduction of the Mexico City Policy (an Executive order that withholds American aid from health organisations that provide or even discuss abortion), that hostility has spiked, with abusive tweets filling our social media feeds. This vitriol directed at Mexican women is infuriating on so many levels and inaccurate on at least three. But while the temptation is either to howl in rage or dismiss it as 'just another tweet', these digital outbursts are symptomatic of the misinformation that persists around abortion and the stigmatisation of women who choose to end a pregnancy. Country director for Marie Stopes Mexico

Denied! Rejection - one of the harshest parts of life. If there is one experience that all we humans have faced in our life that would be the pain of rejectio... Katiâ€™s Chronicles: Imagine yourself locked inside your own body

If Universal Credit Rollout Continues, Foodbanks Won't Be Able To Catch Everyone Who Falls What we must not become is a charity safety net that catches people because our benefits system is fundamentally flawed. Not just for moral or ethical reasons, but because all of the evidence on Universal Credit leads us to believe that even with the enormous generosity of our donors and the hard work and sacrifice of our volunteers and staff, we will simply not be able to catch everybody who falls. Head of Media and External Affairs at The Trussell Trust

Combien dâ€™agriculteurs se suicident?

Si les fromagers artisans ne transforment quâ€™une goutte de lait produite par les quelque 5 600 fermes laitiÃ¨res du QuÃ©bec, ils sont le porte-Ã©tendard dâ€™une industrie qui gÃ©nÃ¨re prÃ¨s de 30 % de toutes les recettes agricoles de la province.



Selon la doctorante, le mÃ©tier dâ€™agriculteur est reconnu comme l'un des plus Ã  risque de stress Ã  cause dâ€™Ã©lÃ©ments incontrÃ´lables comme la mÃ©tÃ©o. Mais la mondialisation, les traitÃ©s commerciaux, le prix du lait, le prix du quota, lâ€™endettement des entreprises, les changements technologiques, les conflits familiaux, les chicanes de couple ou lâ€™isolement sont tous des facteurs de stress qui sâ€™additionnent et font grimper le taux de la dÃ©tresse psychologique. Â« Jusquâ€™Ã  ce que lâ€™Ã©lastique pÃ¨te Â», explique celle qui a Ã©tudiÃ© le malaise des agriculteurs tant au QuÃ©bec quâ€™en France et en Suisse1.



Toutefois, la seule Ã©tude disponible sur le taux de suicide des agriculteurs quÃ©bÃ©cois indiquait quâ€™il Ã©tait le double de celui des hommes dans la population gÃ©nÃ©rale quÃ©bÃ©coise. Mais cette Ã©tude2 rÃ©alisÃ©e par SantÃ© Canada date de trente ans (1971-1987). Le problÃ¨me, pour obtenir lâ€™heure juste, câ€™est que lâ€™Institut national de la santÃ© publique du QuÃ©bec ne comptabilise pas les suicides par profession. En 2014, 845 QuÃ©bÃ©cois se sont enlevÃ© la vie et, depuis 1981, cette triste statistique annuelle oscille entre 795 et 1284 hommes.



Parmi les pays dÃ©veloppÃ©s, la France sâ€™est toutefois dotÃ©e en 2013 dâ€™un Observatoire national du suicide qui dÃ©nombre 417 suicides chez les hommes agriculteurs entre 2007 Ã  2009, surtout dans les Ã©levages de bovins.



Rudy Ducreux, lâ€™arbre qui cache la forÃªt?



Notre enquÃªte rÃ©vÃ¨le cependant que le phÃ©nomÃ¨ne du suicide des agriculteurs existe bel et bien dans la campagne quÃ©bÃ©coise. Parlez-en Ã  Laurier Gauthier, un voisin de Rudy Ducreux. Lâ€™homme de 67 ans est producteur de lait et copropriÃ©taire avec ses frÃ¨res de la seconde plus grosse Ã©rabliÃ¨re de la Belle Province. Il a offert de nous accompagner Ã  la ferme DucrÃªt.

La vraie raison profonde, les gens partent avec.

â€“ Laurier Gauthier

En chemin, Ã  bord de son camion, M. Gauthier lance devant la ferme dâ€™un de ses voisins. Â« Lui aussi il sâ€™est suicidÃ©. Puis pourtant, il avait de lâ€™argent plein les poches. Il venait de sâ€™acheter une Cadillac. Un bon matin, on apprend quâ€™il sâ€™Ã©tait tirÃ© un coup de 22 en arriÃ¨re des oreilles. Surprise totale Â». Il ajoute avoir connu six personnes, dont cinq producteurs et un employÃ© de ferme, qui se sont enlevÃ© la vie dans un rayon de 12 kilomÃ¨tres de son entreprise.



Quant au geste irrÃ©mÃ©diable de Rudy Ducreux, M. Gauthier lâ€™explique peut-Ãªtre par une charge de travail trop lourde pour un seul homme, mais, Â« la vraie raison profonde, les gens partent avec Â», dit-il. Maire de Saint-Basile durant une trentaine dâ€™annÃ©es, le producteur pointe du doigt lâ€™actuel contexte socio-Ã©conomique comme facteur important de dÃ©tresse psychologique chez les producteurs agricoles. Il reproche Ã  QuÃ©bec, depuis le rÃ¨gne du ministre de lâ€™Agriculture pÃ©quiste Jean Garon (1976-1985), champion de la souverainetÃ© alimentaire, de nommer des ministres de lâ€™Agriculture Ã  temps partiel ou ignorant des enjeux.



Quant au fÃ©dÃ©ral, le producteur se demande jusquâ€™oÃ¹ Ottawa, dans lâ€™actuelle renÃ©gociation de lâ€™ALENA exigÃ©e par le prÃ©sident Donald Trump, est prÃªt Ã  dÃ©fendre la gestion de lâ€™offre et ne pas la sacrifier au profit des secteurs du bois dâ€™Å“uvre, de lâ€™automobile ou de lâ€™aviation.



Nous arrivons Ã  la ferme DucrÃªt. Rudy Ducreux avait achetÃ© en 2004 la ferme de Luc Mailloux, un ex-fromager au lait cru, et frÃ¨re du psychiatre controversÃ© Pierre Â« Doc Â» Mailloux. Sur place, nous sommes accueillis par Connie McLellan, une jeune agricultrice de 28 ans originaire de Nouvelle-Ã‰cosse. Elle hÃ©site Ã  parler au journaliste, selon les conseils de lâ€™avocat engagÃ© par la succession Â« pour ne pas nuire Ã  la vente de la ferme Â», prÃ©vue dâ€™ici lâ€™automne. Le corps de Rudy Ducreux a depuis longtemps Ã©tÃ© rapatriÃ© par la famille.



Connie McLellan, une jeune productrice, s'occupe du troupeau de Rudy Ducreux.



La jeune femme explique avoir Ã©tÃ© recrutÃ©e pour traire le troupeau de 26 bÃªtes. Ã€ part le cliquetis des chaÃ®nes des vaches Ã  lâ€™Ã©table, le silence rÃ¨gne autour de la maison, de la fromagerie, de lâ€™Ã©tabli et des remises dÃ©sertÃ©s. Seul un chat en manque de caresses nous suit dâ€™un bÃ¢timent Ã  lâ€™autre.



Dans les champs adjacents, de la machinerie rouille au milieu de hautes herbes. Et on peut apercevoir de nouvelles plantations dâ€™arbres sur les terres voisines autrefois cultivÃ©es. Comme lâ€™arbre qui cache la forÃªt, le suicide du crÃ©ateur du Gaulois de Portneuf cache un pan de lâ€™agriculture quÃ©bÃ©coise en pÃ©ril.



-----

1 Droz, Y., MiÃ©ville-Ott, V., Jacques-Jouvenot, D. et Lafleur, G. (2014). Malaise en agriculture. Une approche interdisciplinaire des politiques agricoles France-QuÃ©bec-Suisse. Paris, France : Karthala.

Dr William Pickett, Ã©tude sur le suicide des agriculteurs canadiens, SantÃ© Canada 1971-1987





AUSSI DANS CE DOSSIER:

TEXT:
Sicherheitsforscher der Katholischen UniversitÃ¤t LÃ¶wen haben gravierende SicherheitslÃ¼cken in dem VerschlÃ¼sselungsprotokoll WPA2 entdeckt, mit dem WLAN-Hotspots abgesichert werden. | Milton Brown via Getty Images

Sicherheitsforscher in Belgien haben eine gravierende WLAN-SicherheitslÃ¼cke aufgedeckt

Damit ist das heimische WLAN nicht mehr sicher - ein Update kann hier helfen

Worauf Nutzer achten mÃ¼ssen, darÃ¼ber sind sich Experten nicht einig

Sicherheitsforscher der Katholischen UniversitÃ¤t LÃ¶wen haben gravierende SicherheitslÃ¼cken in dem VerschlÃ¼sselungsprotokoll WPA2 entdeckt, mit dem WLAN-Hotspots abgesichert werden. Mit der "KRACK" getauften Attacke kÃ¶nnen demnach Angreifer die WPA2-VerschlÃ¼sselung aufbrechen, belauschen und manipulieren, berichtete der belgische Sicherheitsforscher Mathy Vanhoef.

Das Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) der USA warnte einem Bericht von "ArsTechnica" zufolge bereits vor den Folgen der entdeckten LÃ¼cken.

Was bedeutet das fÃ¼r WLAN-Nutzer?

Ãœber die Konsequenzen aus der KRACK-Attacke waren sich Experten am Anfang der Woche nicht einig:

â–º Fachleute der Wifi Alliance verwiesen darauf, dass zusÃ¤tzliche VerschlÃ¼sselungs-Schichten wie HTTPS (beispielsweise beim Online-Banking) oder virtuelle private Netzwerke (VPN) durch die KRACK-Attacke nicht ausgehebelt werden. Daher seien auch Online-Banking oder die Kommunikation mit WhatsApp Ã¼ber WLAN weiterhin sicher.

â–º Das Bundesamt fÃ¼r Sicherheit in der Informationstechnik (BSI) dagegen riet am Montagabend dazu, bis zur VerfÃ¼gbarkeit auf Online-Banking in einem mit WPA2 gesicherten WLAN zu verzichten.

Auch vom Einkaufen im Netz via WLAN riet das BSI ab, obwohl quasi alle Online-HÃ¤ndler einen verschlÃ¼sselten Ãœbertragungsweg anbieten, der nicht von dem WPA2-Standard des WLANs abhÃ¤ngt. Das kabelgebundene Surfen dagegen sei sicher.

Aber: "Mir erscheint die generelle Warnung vor Online-Banking und Shopping im eigenen WLAN als Ã¼berzogen, wenn die KanÃ¤le jeweils selbst (mit https:// oder VPN) verschlÃ¼sselt sind", sagte der Sprecher des Chaos Computer Clubs, Linus Neumann, der Deutschen Presse-Agentur.

Denn: "Man kann bei korrekt verifizierten SSL- oder VPN-Verbindungen die Schwachstelle gelassen sehen. Allerdings wissen Laien nicht immer, was alles zu beachten ist, um eine SSL-Verbindung korrekt zu Ã¼berprÃ¼fen. Vermutlich rÃ¤t das BSI daher an dieser Stelle zu einer erhÃ¶hten VorsichtsmaÃŸnahme."

Was ist WPA2? WPA2 ist ein VerschlÃ¼sselungsverfahren zur Absicherung eins WLANs, das bislang als sicher galt. Ã„ltere Standards wie WPA und WEP wurden schon vor Jahren als nicht mehr sicher ausgemustert. Die Forscher in LÃ¶wen entdeckten nach eigenen Angaben nun einen Fehler in dem vierstufigen Verfahren, mit dem bei WPA2 die SchlÃ¼ssel von Sender und EmpfÃ¤nger in einem WLAN ausgetauscht werden. Im dritten Schritt kann der SchlÃ¼ssel mehrmals gesendet werden. Diese SicherheitslÃ¼cke habe ermÃ¶glicht, die VerschlÃ¼sselung zu knacken. Mit WPA2 soll zum einen dafÃ¼r gesorgt werden, dass sich nur berechtigte Nutzer in ein WLAN einloggen kÃ¶nnen. Das VerschlÃ¼sselungsverfahren soll aber auch verhindern, dass die drahtlos Ã¼bertragenen Daten von Unbefugten mitgeschnitten werden kÃ¶nnen. AuÃŸerdem verhindert die VerschlÃ¼sselung, dass Daten auf dem Ãœbertragungsweg manipuliert werden.

Was kÃ¶nnen Nutzer jetzt tun?

â–º Vanhoef erklÃ¤rte, es bringe jetzt nichts, sein WLAN-Passwort zu Ã¤ndern, da dies nicht vor der Attacke schÃ¼tze. Vermutlich seien GerÃ¤te aller Hersteller von den Fehlern betroffen.

Die LÃ¼cken kÃ¶nnten allerdings durch ein Software-Update geschlossen werden. Die Branche mÃ¼sse dabei nicht auf einen neuen Standard WPA3 warten.

â–º Anwender sollten sich nun bei den Herstellern ihrer WLAN-GerÃ¤te nach einem "Patch" erkundigen.

Die US-amerikanischen NetzwerkausrÃ¼ster Aruba und Ubiquiti stellen bereits Sicherheitsupdates zur VerfÃ¼gung.

Das Berliner Unternehmen AVM, Hersteller der in Deutschland populÃ¤ren Fritzbox, erklÃ¤rte, man werde "falls notwendig wie gewohnt ein Update bereitstellen".

So gefÃ¤hrlich ist "KRACK"

Im Gegensatz zu anderen kritischen SicherheitslÃ¼cken wie dem berÃ¼chtigten "Heartbleed"-Fehler kÃ¶nnen Angreifer bei "KRACK" ihre Attacken nicht millionenfach Ã¼ber das Netz ausfÃ¼hren, sondern mÃ¼ssen sich jeweils in der rÃ¤umlichen NÃ¤he des WLAN-Hotspots aufhalten.

Das betonten auf fÃ¼hrende IT-Unternehmen wie Microsoft. AuÃŸerdem mÃ¼sse der Angreifer demnach in der Lage sein, eine technisch aufwendige "Man-in-the-middle"-Attacke auszufÃ¼hren.

Auch Vanhoef rÃ¤umte ein, dass manche entdeckte Angriffsszenarien schwierig umzusetzen seien. "Das sollte aber nicht zur FehleinschÃ¤tzung fÃ¼hren, dass die Attacken in der Praxis nicht zu einem Missbrauch fÃ¼hren kÃ¶nnen."

â–º Bislang gibt es nach Auskunft des Branchenverbandes WiFi Alliance keine Anzeichen dafÃ¼r, dass die von den Forschern entdeckten SicherheitslÃ¼cken in WPA2 bereits von Computerkriminellen ausgenutzt werden.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Windows 10: Fall Creators Update gibt's ab Dienstag - was ihr wissen mÃ¼sst

(ll)
TITLE: WLAN-Router von SicherheitslÃ¼cke betroffen: Was Nutzer jetzt wissen mÃ¼ssen

TEXT:
Endometriosis affects one in 10 women of reproductive age, but despite its prevalence, thereâ€™s still a lack of public awareness around the condition.

The illness causes sufferers to experience painful or heavy periods, pain during sex and fertility issues - all of which are sensitive subjects.

But in an essay for Glamour, Lena Dunham revealed she is often bombarded by questions about personal issues - particularly her fertility - from those who donâ€™t realise how serious endometriosis is.

â€œIâ€™ve had virtual strangers asking whether Iâ€™m fertile, if I plan to freeze my eggs, and how I feel about adoption,â€ she said.

â€œI talk about my illness to normalise it for other women, not to invite dialogue about every aspect of my private life, including my desires around motherhood.â€

In light of her comments, we asked seven other women with endometriosis what they wish people would stop saying to them.

Jim Spellman via Getty Images Lena Dunham.

1. â€œItâ€™s a normal part of being a woman.â€

Kylie Abreu, 31, diagnosed with endometriosis in March 2017, aged 30.

â€œI was often hospitalised because I would pass out from the pain of endometriosis and almost every time I was greeted with an instant dismissal to my pain. I was told that it was â€˜a normal part of being a womanâ€™ and that I just had a low pain tolerance.

â€œIt enraged me. I couldnâ€™t believe that people thought passing out and vomiting from â€˜period painâ€™ was normal. I felt like I was instantly categorised as an overdramatic weak woman who was looking for attention.

â€œThis attitude can make you feel alone and very self-conscious. Whenever I would have an episode I felt embarrassed and ashamed as if it was my fault. When I was finally taken seriously, doctors found a cyst on my ovary that was rapidly growing and almost wreaked havoc on my digestive system and fertility. It is important to understand that this is more than just period pain.â€

2. â€œTry a hot water bottle.â€

Lex Talonted, 33, diagnosed with endometriosis in 2015, aged 31.

â€œThe main thing that frustrates me is the unsolicited advice that people offer. I know that itâ€™s typically coming from a nice place and they just want to help, but it often shows how ignorant people are about the condition.

â€œFor example, if I tell someone that I had to miss work because I couldnâ€™t get out of bed, and they reply with â€˜you should try a hot water bottle, it always really helps me at my time of the monthâ€™.

â€œThat is not only unhelpful but it also really trivialises the condition. I think endometriosis is very misunderstood, even among other women, so it can be hard to make people grasp its severity and just how much it disrupts your life.â€

3. â€œYouâ€™re being a drama queen.â€

Jane Austin, 52, diagnosed with endometriosis in 1989, aged 24.

â€œThe things I hated the most were the uninformed, and subsequently, loaded comments, which undermined me. Unfortunately these came from both sexes:

â€˜youâ€™re imagining itâ€™, â€˜you and your gynae problemsâ€™, â€˜such a drama queenâ€™.

â€œWhen I was diagnosed the female doctor said that my fertility was affected and that I shouldnâ€™t wait too long to have children and that I shouldnâ€™t have focussed on my career. I was a 24 year-old editorial assistant living in a housing association, I hardly think Iâ€™d spent my most fertile years climbing the greasy corporate pole, ignoring my reproductive purpose. She also said that sheâ€™d decided not to have children and that she was fine with it. Fucking great. So the other thing I hated was the presumption.

â€œEvery few years I would ask my doctors if there was new medication and they would ask why I was asking. I would say that I was in a different stage in my life and perhaps another form of treatment might be more suitable or perhaps there had been some medical innovation. Nothing.

â€œAfter Iâ€™d been on Provera for 27 years I asked again if there was another drug and apparently there was. Wonderful, I asked how it was different or better? â€˜Itâ€™s cheaper,â€™ came the reply.â€

4. â€œWhen are you going to have children?â€

Jess Austin, 23, diagnosed with endometriosis October 2017, aged 23.

â€œI was only recently diagnosed, so havenâ€™t been on the receiving end of infuriating comments yet, but I can already foresee them. Every woman knows that they will inevitably be asked when they plan on having kids with their partner, I mean, Iâ€™ve already been asked multiple times and Iâ€™m only 23.

â€œI have always wanted kids (not yet, but someday), but I now know that it wonâ€™t be a simple route. I will have to be weaned off my pill, to have it replaced by another pill for a year, and will then be monitored.

â€œFortunately, I was diagnosed early enough that my fertility has not been impacted but I know that when that question arises again, it wonâ€™t be as simple as laughing it off. The question will hurt.â€

5. â€œDonâ€™t tell your employer.â€

Sofie Hartley, 27, diagnosed with endometriosis in 2013, aged 23.

â€œItâ€™s incredibly important to discuss your endometriosis with your employer because there are going to be days where youâ€™re going to need to see a doctor, a consultant, a specialist, you may need surgery, or youâ€™re generally feeling unwell and youâ€™re not able to make it in work. Your employer will, most likely, be more sympathetic.

â€œBut other than that, youâ€™re starting a conversation. Your employer, be them male or female, may not understand or know what endometriosis is, but isnâ€™t that what bringing awareness is all about, starting a conversation?

â€œEndometriosis sufferers are now protected under the equality act, so there is no reason why you shouldnâ€™t tell your employer about your endometriosis, nor should you feel like you should stay silent about a disease that is as common as diabetes in the UK. You have a right to work, but more importantly, you have a right to work without prejudice.â€

6. â€œYouâ€™re a flakey friend.â€

Holly Leppard, 34, diagnosed with endometriosis in 2015, aged 32.

â€œPlease donâ€™t joke about me being a â€˜sick noteâ€™. I understand I may not be as reliable as most people but Iâ€™d rather you not make light of my situation.

â€œAround 90% of my life is spent trying to cope with the sensation that my uterus is trying to break out of my body; sometimes by brutally stabbing its way out or sometimes by twisting and turning with a slowly grinding blade. Iâ€™m sorry that it annoys you when I cancel last minute or suggest another plan for our day together. It annoys me too.

â€œBelieve me when I say, Iâ€™d prefer to be enjoying a day of walking in the fresh air, eating lunch and (probably) drinking wine with you. Iâ€™ll just be over here, crying in bed, feeling faint and nauseous from the severe pain.

â€œI know itâ€™s hard to understand when someone suffers from an invisible illness, particularly when I may have been seemingly fine last week when I was out with some old friends. I guarantee I wasnâ€™t feeling great.â€

7. â€œNothing...â€

Elizabeth Sparkes, 36, diagnosed with endometriosis in 2009, aged 28.

â€œPlease stop saying...nothing. Most people close to me who understand are very empathic, but then there are people who donâ€™t realise how awful it is, or what it is. We need to raise awareness and explain how debilitating this is emotionally and physically.

â€œHaving an illness that is hidden and not widely understood has left me feeling embarrassed in the past and I have often wanted to hide it from people, especially colleagues. Having time off work for operations is so hard as I wonder whether people really get it, how bad it can be. I feel terribly guilty at times. A part of this guilt is emphasised by the illness being hidden.

â€œIf we could educate about it more widely I think it may help those diagnosed to feel validated and understood. I will be having a hysterectomy soon, itâ€™s the only option now due to damage, but the psychological part is the hardest to make peace with.â€

7 Celebrities With Endometriosis
TITLE: 7 Things Women With Endometriosis Want You To Stop Saying
